She now lives in common law marriage with Hector Enrique Castellanos who raises cattle. Their home and four children are supported by them. She helps her partner pay for the cost of food, housing, health and education for their children with the income from her business. She will use the loan to buy cleaning products, moisturizers and lotions.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of household cleaning products, moisturizers and lotions.

loans.name: Basilia

texts.en:
Basilia T. is from the town of Talibon. She is 63 years old and is married. Basilia owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Basilia's husband makes furniture for a living and she helps him sell his products in their community.

Basilia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Basilia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Basilia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to invest in improving her husband's business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Math

texts.en: Math A., 54, is a widowed mother blessed with four children: two are single and two are married and live separately. Math A. currently buys and sells used goods to earn a living. One of her single children assists her in operating the business. Math A. owns a trailer that she currently uses to transport the used goods, but it is too small side and unable to carry all of the items. Thus, she proposes to use her loan money to purchase another trailer, which will allow her to transport more used goods. Math A. intends to use the rest of the loan to increase her business capital.

loans.use: to purchase a trailer and to increase her business capital

loans.name: Yeni Xiomara

texts.es:
la sra. Yeni Xiomara P. se dedica al comercio, tiene una pequeña pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación en la cual tiene 2  años de experiencia y de administración de la misma.
Además de tener la pulpería también se dedica a la venta de cosméticos actividad a la cual se dedica de forma domiciliaria y ambulante, cuando sale a vender su hijo se queda ayudándole en la pulpería.
Doña Yeni es madre soltera y de ella solo depende su hijo el cual ha sacado adelante con las ganancias obtenidas de su negocio además a pagado los gastos de educación y alimentacion del mismo.
Es notable que Doña Yeni a sabido administrar su negocio ya que el crecimiento de este es notable. 
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de mercaderia para surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Yeni Xiomara Pavón is a grocer; she has a small grocery store in her home. She has two years experience in this line of work and in running the store. Besides the grocery store she also sells cosmetics from door to door and itinerantly. When she goes out to sell her son stays to watch the store. Yeni is a single mother and has a son who depends on her. Profits from the business have been used to pay for her son’s nutrition and schooling. It is notable that Yeni has known how to run her business because it has grown considerably. The loan will be used to buy stock items for the store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy lard, cooking oil, beans, rice, sugar, coffee, corn and wheat flour, soups, salt, eggs, dairy products, soft drinks, juices, soap, churros (deep fried dough sprinkled with sugar and cinnamon).

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena D., 58, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Bernardo D., a driver. They are blessed in their marriage with good health and strong physiques which enable them to work hard for their future together.

Elena operates a ready-to-wear clothing store. She mainly offers children’s clothing, summer shorts (which are very popular in tropical Philippines), statement shirts, and other basic everyday wear. The clothing is made from sheer cotton fabrics, which are all suited to the hot and humid climate. Most customers only buy made-to-order clothes when really necessary, as it is more expensive. Elena’s customers are her immediate community and neighbors.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities and designs of clothing to replenish and increase her current business inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Elena has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for almost 8 years now and regularly attends fellowship meetings*.
 
Elena dreams of being able to have her own house and lot someday through all her hard work in her business.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship group gathers each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more clothing to replenish and increase her current business inventory

loans.name: Lubna's Group

texts.en:
Lubna is 39 years old and is married to U. D.. She has lived in the small city of Chichawatni since she got married. Chichawatni is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is known for its agriculture. Lubna is a housewife and the mother of three children: two girls and a boy, all of whom are attending school and getting their education. Lubna lives in a three room brick house and spends most of her time with her family by staying at home.

Lubna’s husband operates a used clothing business. He buys the clothes from different shops at the market and sells them on his cart by going to different areas of the community. He specifically deals with children's clothes. He earns a good income from it because he buys clothes at cheap prices and sells them at a good profit. In this way, he provides financially for his family. With the earned profit, he manages his children's school fees.

Lubna has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband upgrade his business. He will use the loan amount to buy used clothes in large quantities and sell them for a good profit. Lubna is hopeful that her husband will be able to successfully improve his business with the loan money. Lubna is a regular lender with Asasah and is in her 3rd loan cycle. In her previous loan years, she has proved to be a responsible client who always paid her installments on time and attended meetings regularly.

loans.use: Purchase used clothes for resale

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia T., age 44, has three children, one in college, one in high school, and one in elementary school, and works hard to cover her family's daily expenses and the cost of her children's education. Celia has owned and run a sari-sari (general store) for ten years, and relies on the income she generates from the business. 

Celia is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to help her purchase additional rice for her store. She hopes that the additional inventory will allow her to expand the business and generate additional revenue for her family.

Celia has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2008 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.* She hopes that one day she will be able to move her store to a bigger space and be able to fully fund her children's education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase inventory

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es:
La Sra. Teresa de Jesus I. se dedica al comercio, tiene 10 años de haber iniciado con la venta de abarrotería, mismo que opera bajo el nombre de Pulpería “HEYDI”.

La Sra. I. a sabido ganar la clientela por la atención y amabilidad con que atiende; en su negocio se encuentra un buen surtido de productos de lo mas importante para el consumo diario como ser: Arroz, manteca, azúcar, huevos, jabón, pollo, detergentes, etc…
Doña Teresa es soltera y vive en casa de sus padres cuidándolos a ambos y fue así como ella tomo la decisión de dedicarse al negocio para no solo cuidarlos si no tener una fuente de ingresos que le permitiera cuidar mucho mejor de ellos por que ya son de edad avanzada mismos que depende en su totalidad de ella.
texts.en:
Teresa de Jesus works in commerce. Ten years ago she started a general store named "Pulperia Heydi". She has built her clientele by attending to her clients with friendliness and attention. She has a good variety of first necessity products in her business such as rice, butter, sugar, eggs, soap, chicken, detergents and others. Teresa is single and lives and cares for her parents in their home. She decided to have her own business so that she could not only take care of her parents but also have a source of income to better provide for them. Her parents are of advanced age and depend solely on her.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bread, cookies, sugar, flour, eggs, spread, butter, oil, beans, tortillas, soap, "churros", spaghetti, pasta, salsas, mints, toothpaste, toilet paper, oat, juice.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita G. is from the town of Talibon. She is 46 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she operates a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over twelve years.

Lolita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to repair the fishing boat. This will be her 1st loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: to repair the fishing boat

loans.name: Ana Victoria

texts.es:
La Sra. Ana N. se dedica a vender una gran variedad de cosméticos, ella tiene 7 años de haber iniciado con este negocio y es notable que durante este tiempo lo a sabido administrar, ya que su crecimiento es evidente,  su negocio opera bajo el nombre de “ANAS”
Doña Ana tomo la decisión de dedicarse a este tipo de actividad ya que ella vive sola con sus 2 hijos por que su esposo migro para los EE.UU en busca de mejorar sus condiciones de vida y con las remesas que recibe de su esposo ella lo invierte en mejorar su vivienda.-  y con lo que le genera su negocio cubre a un 100% sus gastos personales y las de sus hijos, sus dos hijos en la actualidad están cursando sus estudios primarios.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de mercaderia y asi surtir un poco mas su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ana N. is a cosmetics merchant; she started the business 7 years ago and its evident growth is proof that she’s known how to run it well. She sells a wide range of products and the business operates under the name”ANAS.” Ana decided to take on this business because she lives alone with her two children because her husband emigrated to the United States seeking better living conditions. The allowance he sends her are used for home improvements and what she earns from her business is 100% used for her own and her children’s personal expenses. Her two children are currently in primary school. The loan will be used to buy merchandise to increase her store’s stock.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy creams, lotions, perfumes, hair gel, sandals, shoes, athletic shoes, nail polish, shampoo, conditioners, deodorants, baby oil.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani lives in a three-room brick house in a small city of south Punjab, Pakistan, called Chichawatni, which is famous for its agriculture. Rani is 20 years of age, born in Chichawatni and grew up here. She got married at an early age to M. A. who has manufactured furniture for the last ten years.
She has two children, 2 year old Akram and 4 month old Rizwan. She is a housewife who takes care of her family by staying at home.
  
Rani’s husband is in need of money because he wants to buy wood in bulk to fill a large order. Therefore, Rani has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband in this regard. She is hopeful that by investing money in her husband’s business, he will be able to make good profits as a result of fulfilling larger orders. She also hopes that an increase in income will make it possible for her family to enjoy a better standard of living and that she will be able to educate her children once they become older. 

She is a new loan user of Asasah and she is expecting that it will be a good experience for her.

loans.use: Purchase wood for furniture-making business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buying tools for his auto workshop

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Joice S. is currently in the business of selling beans, rice and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize flour and onions to sell.  Joice is 40 years old and is married to a peasant. She has eight children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a proper shop for keeping her goods saved from rains.

loans.use: Stock bags of maize flour and onions to sell

loans.name: Ma. Merlin

texts.en:
Ma. Merlin E. is from the town of Talibon. She is 36 years old, married, and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, she operates a fishing business, catching and selling assorted fish to the market. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years.

Ma. Merlin joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a  loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. This will be her 1st loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets

loans.name: Unis

texts.en:
Unis P. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and bread at home. She is requesting a loan to stock firewood and more bags of charcoal to sell. 

Unis is 42 years old and married to a peasant. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock firewood and more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.es:
la sra. Maria N. M. tiene cinco años de dedicarse a la venta de abarrotaría, negocio que Opera bajo el nombre de pulpería “MISHELL”, su negocio es uno de los mas surtidos y con mayor demanda de la zona además de todo se a sabido ganar su clientela, debido a su amabilidad, por lo que su negocio continua en crecimiento.
Doña Maria, es madre soltera de una niña la cual depende a un 100% de ella y con los ingresos que le genera su negocio cubre en su totalidad los gastos del hogar.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas mercaderia y surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria N. M. has been selling groceries for five years, a business she operates as the Mishell Store. Her business is one of the best-stocked and with the highest demand in the area. Besides everything else, Maria has known how to gain customers because of her friendliness, and this is why her business keeps growing. Doña Maria is a single mother with a daughter who depends 100% on her, and with the income from her business she covers all household expenses. She will use the loan to buy more merchandise and stock her store.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Eggs, beans, rice, sugar, lard, oil, grains, butter, cheese, ham, sausage, pork, beef, chicken, soft drinks, coffee, cookies, donuts, balls, light bulbs, matches, candles, batteries

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
This is Melinda M., 46, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Rogelio M., a mechanic, and is mother to a five young adults, four of whom are already working while the youngest is in college. By the grace of God, Melinda has managed to support all her children’s educational needs. As of the present time, she is working hard to be able to maintain her finances for her youngest child’s college education.

Melinda operates an auto-repair shop. Her husband is the main mechanic while she handles the finances, accounts, inventories and promotion. They offer repair, check-ups and beautification of all types of cars, jeepneys and any type of vehicle that is referred to them.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 25,000 Philippine pesos loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy supplies like wiring, putty paint and others of the like. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. She has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for years now and regularly attends fellowship meetings.*  

Melinda dreams to be able to give her child a high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship co-members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy supplies like wiring, putty paint and others of the like

loans.name: Chamreoun's Group

texts.en:
B. Chamreong, 33 years old is the village bank president, having been selected by its ten members, who are located in Preak Toch village, Kandal province. 

The members will use the money to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.

B. and her husband fish for a living.  They are able provide a small income to support the family.  B. will use the loan to buy a fishing boat and supplies for fishing.  They have seven children: five are students and also help their parents and the others stay at home.

loans.use: Buy fishing boat and supplies.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and maize at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans and millet to sell. Jane is 29 years old and married to a nurse. She has two children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house for rent.

loans.use: Stock bags of beans and millet to sell

loans.name: Irshaad's Group

texts.en:
Irshaad lives in a small city called Chichawatni, which is famous for its agriculture industry.  It is located near Multan, Pakistan. 

She lives with her family in a four room brick house in the area of Al-Fateh. She is a 43-year-old mother of two sons and a daughter who moved here fifteen years ago with her husband. Both of her sons are illiterate and operate their separate grocery shops in the market. Her daughter is 16 years old and studying in ninth grade.

Irshaad operates her business selling clothes, which she purchases from Multan and sells to her community and to cloth shops. Irshaad started her clothes-selling business two years ago. She has applied for a loan for her own business. With the loan amount, she will buy clothes in bulk. This purchasing in bulk will allow her to cut the cost of travelling and also to offer more variety to her clients.

Another source of income for Irshaad’s family is rent; they have rented out the upper portion of their house for about 3500 Pakistan Rupees per month.  She is hopeful that she will be able to increase her income by investing in her business.

Irshaad is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan cycle. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for reselling

loans.name: Francy Locadith

texts.es:
el sr. Francy Locadith M. I. se dedica a la elaboracion de prótesis Dentales, a su vez también realiza extracciones de piezas dentales, negocio que opera bajo el nombre de “Laboratorio Dental M.” 
El señor Francy cuenta con 16 años experiencia en este negocio.
Debido a que en la zona en donde esta ubicado su laboratorio no existen clínicas dentales y la amabilidad con la que el Señor Francy atiende a sus clientes a el acuden la mayoría de personas de la aldea así como de todos los lugares aledaños.
Don Francy es casado pero no tiene hijos con su esposa y ella se dedica a los oficios domésticos dentro del hogar.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar materiales y los medicamentos necesarios para las extracciones.
texts.en:
Francy Locadith M. I. works making dental prostheses, and he also carries out tooth extractions. He operates this business under the name "M. Dental Laboratory." He has 16 years of experience with this business. Thanks to the fact that there are no dental clinics in the area where his laboratory is located, and the friendliness with which Francy treats his clients, most people in the town, as well as many from more distant areas, come to him. Francy is married but has no children with his wife, who dedicates herself to domestic tasks within the home. He will use the loan to buy supplies and medications that he needs to carry out extractions.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying supplies and medications

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maria Erlinda

texts.en:
Maria Erlinda A. is from the town of Talibon. She is 46 years old. Maria Erlinda is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Maria Erlinda owns & operates a farm. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Maria Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over three years. She also runs a small sari-sari (general) store that she hopes to grow as well.

Maria Erlinda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Maria Erlinda is requesting a loan of 6000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maria Erlinda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve their house.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchasing cloth and thread

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice N.  is currently in the business of selling green vegetables, onions and tomatoes. She is requesting a loan to stock dried fish and more tomatoes to sell.  

Joice is 36 years old and married to an electrical technician. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: Stock dried fish and more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: San's Group

texts.en:
San B., age 30, is the village bank president, having been selected by its ten members who are located in Preak Toch village, Kandal province. Each member of this village will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses. 

San and her husband are fishermen who earn a small income to support their family.  San will use the loan to buy a fishing boat and fishing machine. They work very hard to support their six children:  Three are students and the other three are stay at home.

loans.use: Buy fishing boat and fishing machine for fishing.

loans.name: Zulaikhan's Group

texts.en:
Zulaikhan is a resident of a small city called Chichawatni, which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is well known for its agriculture industry. 

She is 28 years old and got married when she was only 16. She is the mother of six daughters. None of them could get an education because Zulaikhan and her husband didn’t have enough resources to pay for their school fees.
 
Her husband is illiterate. He sells clothes and is the only breadwinner in the family. He operates his small shop in the market. He imports clothes from Multan, Lahore and Faisalabad and sells them through his shop. 

Life is not easy for Zulaikhan and her family as her husband’s income is not enough for fulfilling the basic needs of the family. Therefore, Zulaikhan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy clothes in bulk to reduce the cost of traveling and to offer more variety to his clients.

Zulaikhan hopes that this investment will help her husband in improving his business and her family will be able to improve its living standard. She is a new loan applicant and she is expecting that it will be a profitable experience for her.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for a clothes-selling business

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida L. is currently in the business of selling both fresh and dried fish at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes, onions and jerrycans of cooking to sell.  

Saida is 24 years old and married to a driver. She has two children, one of whom goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock tomatoes, onions and jerrycans of cooking to sell

loans.name: Prudencia

texts.en:
Prudencia T. is from the town of Talibon. She is 48 years old. Prudencia is married and has five school-aged children. She is a fish vendor. She buys fish from fishermen and sells them at her stall. She hopes to acquire other products that she could sell. She also wants to save to improve her stall.

Prudencia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Prudencia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase fish to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Prudencia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchasing sewing materials

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sewing clothes is the main part of 38-year-old Mrs. Sok C.'s daily duties in the garment industry. Sok C. has been engaged in her job since 2009 and has a formal salary. She has a life partner in her husband, who is an internal staff member for an organization. The couple has married but they do not have any children. 

Sok C. is concerned that she faces difficulties in traveling to her workplace. She and her husband always travel to work by hiring a taxi because they don't have their own vehicle. To solve the problem, Sok C. has requested a loan to be used to buy a new motorcycle to provide transportation without hiring a taxi.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle to provide transportation without hiring a taxi

loans.name: Nuulu

texts.en:
Nuulu is married with eight children and all of them are at school. She also takes care of additional family members (orphans).  She owns a charcoal store at her home in Bwaise. She has been in this charcoal business for eight years.   

She plans to use this loan of 500,000 Ugandan shillings to buy more bags of charcoal. She has no additional income and sells to all people in the area but on a retail basis. She buys bags of charcoal from delivery vans, which get them from villages, so she doesn’t incur any transport costs for her business. She aspires to go to the producers directly. 

She works seven days a week and depends on this job for a living. Nuulu decided to join MCDT because of low interest rate charged. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her  monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty K. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Betty is 41 years old and widowed. She has seven children and four of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Nishaan's Group

texts.en:
Nishaan lives in the small city of Chichawatni, which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is known for its agriculture industry. She is 50 years old and has been living in Chichawatni with her family for the last 22 years. 

She got married to Z. Ahmed and is the mother of four children. Only her youngest two sons are able to get an education due to the poor financial conditions of the family. Nishaan’s eldest son makes shoes and her daughter is a seamstress who sews clothes for neighboring clients. Nishaan is a housewife. She takes care of her family by staying at home.
 
Her husband is a cobbler by profession. He makes shoes by getting orders from different shoe factories and shoe-selling shops and supplying the finished goods on time to make an income. He has been doing this business for the last 10 years and is an expert in his work. His eldest son has learned the skill from him and now helps him in completing the orders on time.
 
Nishaan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, he will buy raw materials, such as glue, leather, nails and shoe polishers, in a larger quantity to help him in completing the orders on time and to make more income. 

This is Nishaan’s first loan application to Asasah. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for the shoe-making business

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther K. is currently in the business of selling bread, groundnut phase (similar to peanut butter), and tomatoes at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock onions and dried fish to sell.  
Esther is 39 years old and is married to a policeman. She has four children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

loans.use: To stock onions and dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Horng

texts.en:
Horng M., 62, is a widowed farmer who lives with her four children in the Takeo province. She typically makes $1.00 U.S. each day, and she would like to increase her profits. 
Horng M. receives additional support from three of her children: two are garment factory workers and one is a hairdresser. Horng M. is requesting a loan of $1,000.00 United States dollars to purchase hairdressing tools for her daughter.

loans.use: To purchase hairdressing tools for her daughter.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is currently in the business of selling sweet potatoes, cassava, and Irish potatoes at the market and she is requesting a loan to stock carrots, yams, and tomatoes to sell.

Mary is 40 years old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

loans.use: To stock carrots, yams, and tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To fix leaking roof.

loans.name: Anarkan's Group

texts.en:
Some women have proved to be successful as providers of families and owners of business. Anarkan D., leader of the group, is one those women. She is 53 and divorced. She raised 4 children alone with the help of her business. Now her elder son is 25 and he works as foreman in the company named “Alyukobond”, her second son works in Russia, her daughter is seamstress and the youngest son is a student. 

But 22 years ago she had to start her business alone in order to provide her children only with a calf that was given by her relatives as a present for the birth of her second child in compliance with Kyrgyz national traditions.  Using the calf meat and initial investments of 3,000 soms, she started doing and then selling meat dumplings. Now she has hired two assistants who make 20 kilograms of meat dumplings a day. Her business brings her 1,000 soms monthly. 

In order to increase her profits she is planning to buy small cattle, fatten it for slaughter and use this meat in making meat dumplings. Unfortunately, she doesn’t have sufficient funds, therefore she is applying for a loan. This loan will help Anarkan reduce the costs on the purchase of meat and as a result increase her profits. 

Group members:
Nargiza D. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 32 and married. She has a son of 14 years.  Her husband is working as a driver on the fish-factory. She works as a seamstress. Still, their wages are not enough to cover their living expenses. Thus, they started seven years ago their own family business. Mainly, this business is on Nargiza because her husband is working in the capital of Kyrgyzstan – Bishkek. When their son became 5, their relatives gave them as a present a calf. With this calf she started her business. She fattened it and then sold it. So this is how she started her business of buying, fattening and selling a calf with the purpose of making profit. Monthly she gets 1,200 soms. For now, due to the successful functioning of her business, she can make capital repairs to her house. She is applying for loan in order to continue her business. But now she wants not just to sell a calf but also she is considering an opportunity of exchanging it for a milk cow and then selling milk in the mornings. 

Ibarat K. is 53 and widow. She has 3 children. Her first son is 23, her second son is 21 and both of them work as builders. Her daughter is 16 and she is student. During her summer break, she works as washerwoman at car wash. Since the situation in the country changed a lot, she lost a job and it forced her to consider options of starting her own business. She decided to breed cattle. She is almost three years in cattle breeding business. She started it with initial investments of 2,000 soms and it brings her monthly 1,700 soms. On the money received as profits from her business, she is able to pay tuition fee for her daughter at her institution of higher education and she could buy household appliances for her house. Now, she needs funds to buy another calf, fatten it and sell it. Therefore, she is applying for a loan which will help her to develop her business. 

Nazarbek K. is 42 and married. He is a builder in the capital of Kyrgyzstan – Bishkek. He has 3 children. The elder son is 15, his second son is 13, his little daughter is 7 and all of them go to school. His wife is working at the grill factory. Still, in order to have enough money to provide his family, he started breeding cattle. Here, his elder son and his wife assist him while he is at work. They started breed cattle upon the advice of his wife’s parents to buy a calf, fatten and sell it. He is 10 years in the cattle-breeding business with an initial investment of 4,000 soms. This business brings 1,300 soms monthly. On the profits from his business, he could provide his family, pay for their education and make partial capital repairs of his house. Now, he applying for a loan to buy a calf, fatten and sell it. After selling it, he is planning to add money and to buy a milk cow and then sell milk. This will help him to increase his profits from business and make him closer to his dream to build a big and beautiful house.   

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase small cattle.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase furniture and other needed items.

loans.name: Voul

texts.en:
Voul T., 34, is a professional silk weaver, making $2.50 United States dollars each day in the Takeo province. She is married and has three children living at home to support. Her husband makes approximately $5.00 U.S. dollars every day as a taxi driver. 

Voul T. would like a loan of $500.00 U.S. dollars to purchase more silk. 

(Note: Voul T. and her husband were not available for the picture so Voul T.'s daughter is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To purchase more silk.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose K. is currently in the business of selling dresses, trousers, and saddles at market and she is requesting a loan to stock shoes to sell.

Rose is 36 years old and is married with a husband who is a teacher. She has three children and her children go to school. 

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock shoes to sell.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa T. is from the village of Talibon. She is 54 years old and is married. 

To make a living, Teresa owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market. Teresa has been engaged in her business for over 10 years.

Teresa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 6,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. 

This loan will be the first loan taken out by Teresa from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets.

loans.name: Aom

texts.en:
Aom O., 59, is married and lives with five of her children in the Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about $1.00 U.S. dollar each day. They are supported by four of their children -- three work in the garment factory and one is a professional silk weaver. 

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Aom O. included. 

In light of these economic difficulties, Aom O. is asking for a loan of $400 United States dollars to purchase fertilizer and silk. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and silk.

loans.name: Nhoem

texts.en: Nhoem P., 30, is a professional silk weaver, making $1.50 each day in the Takeo province. She is married and has two children living at home to support. Her husband, pictured here, is a worker and makes approximately $2.50 every day. Nhoem P. would like a loan of $600 to raise cows.

loans.use: To raise cows

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is married and has ten children, four of whom are not in school. She also takes care of additional family members. 

She is a tailor of school uniforms and other garments and works from her home. She has been in this tailoring business for eight years. She wants to use this loan to buy more school uniform materials. She buys fabric from Kiyembe shops in Kampala and uses public transport to and from shopping.

Besides this clothing business she owns a public pay phone which brings in additional income. She sells her uniforms to all categories of people at retail prices. She works six days a week and depends on this job for a living.  Her business challenge is the seasonality.  She is hoping to see her business grow big so that she can get enough profit to buy a plot of land to build rental rooms. 

She decided to join MCDT because she wanted additional capital for her business. She owns and resides in a three-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees, food and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bolts of school uniform materials

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary P. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize, millet and peeled dried cassava and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans and rice to sell.  Mary is 39 years old and is married to a security guard. She has four children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store to replace her food stall.

loans.use: Stock bags of beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng K., 56, is married and lives with four of her children in the Takeo province. She and her husband (who is pictured here) are farmers who typically make about $2 each day and are also supported by three of their working children. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Heng K. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase fertilizer. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Parida's Group

texts.en:
In the past, women were keepers of the family hearth. Time passed and women broadened their sphere of activities. Now, along with all their obligations at home, women also assist their husbands in providing for their families. One of those women is Parida A.. She is 43 years old and married. She has three children. Her two older children, a son and a daughter, have married. Her younger son is twelve years old and goes to school. Her husband works as a guard at the Municipal Department of Internal Affairs of Tashkomur city. 

Fourteen years ago, Parida decided to assist her husband and started her business of breeding cattle. She started by purchasing one head of small cattle for 500 KGS with the goal of increasing the number. Now, she has two head of cattle and ten head of small cattle. Her cattle breeding business brings her about $155 annually. She wants to increase the size of the herd by buying five more head of small cattle for breeding. In order to have sufficient funds to purchase them, she applied for a loan. In the future, on the profits from her cattle breeding business, she wants to buy a big house where she is planning to live with her youngest son and her husband. 

Group members:

Zaripa K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 35 years old and married. She has three children. Her elder daughter is 10, her second and third daughters are 8, and all of them go to school. Her husband transports cargo by truck. In 1995, together with her husband, Zaripa decided to start a wholesale business in Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan), buying vegetables and reselling them at higher prices at her town, Tashkomur. Her husband assists her with the wholesale purchase of vegetables in the capital and their transportation to their town (Tashkomur). She started her business with an initial investment of 1,000 KGS and it brings her around $264 monthly. She and her husband have bought a flat in Tashkomur for 100,000 KGS and a truck for 500,000 KGS. She decided to broaden her business, and wants to buy autumn season clothing and school uniforms to sell at higher prices. For this purpose she needs funds, and so she applied for a loan. On the profits from her business,  she and her husband are planning to build a house for their children and to buy a car. 

Baktygul A. is 22 years old and married. She is pregnant and expecting a baby soon. Her husband is a craftsman. Baktygul decided to breed cattle one year ago, and she bought two head of cattle for 6,000 KGS. She has increased the number of cattle to four. During the summer period, they give their cattle to shepherds to graze in the mountains, and during the winter periods her husband's parents help to breed cattle at their house. The cattle breeding business brings her about $132 monthly. She is applying for a loan in order to buy two more head of cattle which she hopes to fatten and then resell at a higher price.

Jazgul K. is 26 years old and married. She has two children. Her elder child is three and her younger child is only 2 months old. Her husband is a guard at the Municipal Department of Internal Affairs of Tashkomur city. In 2008, she decided to buy two head of cattle for 4,000 KGS and breed cattle. She has increased the number of cattle to five. Her business brings her about $132 monthly. She is applying for a loan in order to buy more cattle and fatten them, and then resell them at a higher price. On the profits from her business she is planning to provide for her children and make some savings in order to give them a good education.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more farm animals

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal as well as tomatoes, onions and dried fish to sell.  Mary is 25 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children, two of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal and also tomatoes, onions and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Lay

texts.en: Lay S., 28, is married and lives with her husband and one child in Takeo province. Since 2001, she has been working in a garment factory  and is able to make US$2 a day, while her husband, pictured here, is a carpenter, earning US$3 each day. This family spends US$65 on food, US$5 on utility, US$20 on transportation and US$15 on other expenses. To earn more profit to help raise family’s standard of living, she decided to take out a loan of US$500 to raise cows.

loans.use: To raise cows.

loans.name: Azeezan

texts.en:
Azeezan lives in Kot Radha Kishen. It is a small city located near Lahore, Pakistan and is known for its dairy products.  Azeezan is a 53 years old lady who has given birth to two sons and a daughter. Her eldest son has completed 10th grade and has started a job in the factory as he couldn’t continue his education. The remaining two children are in 9th grade.  

Azeezan’s husband runs a grocery shop and in the evening he sells milk. He has six buffaloes at his home. Azeezan takes care of the buffalos in the absence of her husband and gets milk from them so when her husband comes home from work he can sell the milk without any delay. 

Azeezan lives in a four room brick house. Part of the house is dedicated for the buffalo while other rooms are used by her family. She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband.  His dairy business is going good and giving him good earning.  With the loan he will add large quantities of groceries in  to his grocery shop.  She is hopeful that an investment will result in higher profits from her husband’s business and her family’s financial condition will get better. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan cycle. In previous loan experiences she has proved herself to be a responsible client and has never missed a meeting.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for a grocery shop

loans.name: Pork

texts.en: Pork S., 44, is married and lives with her four children in Takeo province. She is a farmer, who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband is a musician, making US$2 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Pork S. included. Pork S. is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase a motorbike for her family transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Thy's Group

texts.en:
Thy O. 39 years old and is the village bank president having been selected by its eight members which located in Preak Toch village, Kandal province. While each member of this village will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.
 
Thy and her husband are farmers who own a two hectare piece of land to cultivate rice for a living.  Her husband is also a fisherman.  Thy will use the loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline and to pay farm laborers to plow her farm to cultivate rice.  She will also purchase fishing supplies to support her husband's fishing. 

This couple has eight children: two are seamstresses in the garment factory, one is a fisherman and four are students in the local school.  The youngest is age three.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline and to pay farm laborers to plow her farm to cultivate rice

loans.name: Aikumush's Group

texts.en:
Mostly, in developing countries, governments are not able to provide desirable support to their citizens. Thus, people cannot just rely on the help of the government. Therefore, either voluntarily or due to absence of other opportunities, people start up their own business in order to provide for  themselves.

 Aikumush B., leader of this group, is one of those people. She is 53 and married. She has a son of 12 years old and he goes to school. Earlier, her husband was working and providing for the family, but then he retired. The amount of retirement allowance received from the government was 1875 soms, which is not enough to cover living expenses. 

Aikumush tried to find a job but she is 53 and it is well-known that as you get older, your employment chances decrease. One year ago, being tired out from searching for a job, she decided to start her own business – livestock breeding. She started with an initial investment of 2000 soms and now the business brings in 7500 soms monthly. 7500 soms are quite enough to provide for herself and members of her family. Still, she believes that she could increase profits from her business if she had more livestock. Thus, she is applying for a loan in order to buy at least one more sheep.  Increased profits will give her an opportunity to realize her wish to make capital repairs on her home and pay for better education for her son. 

Group members:

Dzhyldyzgul E. is the group treasurer. She is 48 and married. She has a daughter of 5 years old. Her husband is pensioner and his retirement allowance is 1924 soms per month. Like Aikumush, the leader of the group, she was in search of a job during a certain period, but couldn’t find a job. Following the suggestion of her neighbors, 4 years ago, she decided to start up her business – cattle breeding. She started her business from 10,000 soms. For now, she has significantly increased the number of heads of cattle, and cattle breeding gives her 3000 soms monthly. She is applying for a loan in order to buy 8 sheep to fatten and sell.  With the profits received, she is planning to build a new house. 

Kunduz A. is 37 and married. She has 3 children. Her daughter is 7 and her sons are 4 and 1 and a half years old. Her daughter goes to school. Her husband is a guard of an area with crops and he receives 2500 soms. In order to help her husband, 2 years ago, Kunduz  decided to start breeding cattle. She took 15,000 soms from the family budget and bought cattle. She buys cattle, fattens and then sells them at a higher price and it brings her 3500 soms monthly. She has increased the number of heads of cattle and she is planning to increase that number again. With the help of a loan, she will be able to buy 2 more head of cattle in order to continue the functioning of her business and make repairs to her house for the winter period.

Dzhambulat B. is 49 and married. He has two sons, 21 and 13 years old. The younger son goes to school. His wife is a housewife and assists her husband in taking care of their household. He is a taxi driver and his income is 6000 soms monthly. However, 15 years ago, before becoming a taxi driver, he started breeding cattle with an initial investment of 5000 soms. During the last 15 years, it was income from cattle breeding (6000 soms monthly) that helped him to provide for members of his family. Since he is also employed as a taxi driver now, his elder son helps him in breeding cattle. Now, his elder son is planning to get married and thus, they need money in order to put on a small traditional wedding. Thus, they are applying for loan which will give them an opportunity to increase the number of head of cattle, fatten and sell them at a higher price, and increase their profits. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a sheep

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun C., 34, is a professional handicraft-maker living in Takeo province. Since 2005, she has been using beads and other materials to make flowers on women's clothes or pillows to earn a living and typically making US$ 1 each day. Her husband, pictured here, is a moto-taxi driver. On average, he makes US$ 4 in profit a day. This couple has four children living at home to support. Bun C. is asking for a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a trailer for her husband to attach to his motorbike so that he can transport several people in one time.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike trailer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To replace her existing home appliances

loans.name: Am

texts.en:
Am S., 47, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for its quality palm products.

S. sells bread for an income of USD 3.50 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3.50 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a new car for her husband so that he can operate his business efficiently. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.


In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy a new car for her husband's taxi business

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch T., 28, is married and lives with three of her children in Takeo province. She and her husband are musicians who typically make about US$5 each day. Three of her children are now in school. This family spends about US$25 on food, US$5 on utilities, US$5 on their children’s education, US$10 on transportation and US$10 on other expense.

Touch would like to take out a loan of US$600 to raise cows.

loans.use: To raise cows

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong K., 58, is a widowed farmer who lives with three of her children in Takeo province. She typically makes US$1 each day and one of her daughter works selling fruit and grocery products, earning US$4 of profit a day.

Hong K. is asking for a loan of US$500 to invest in her daughter’s business.

loans.use: To invest in her daughter's fruit and grocery business

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin C. is from the town of Talibon. He is 30 years old and is married with two infant children.

Edwin is a carpenter and has been doing carpentry for more than seven years now. His first customers were his friends until people heard of the service he offers and started calling on him.

Edwin joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his first from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Roza's Group

texts.en: Roza H., leader of this group, is 23 and married. She is one of those lucky women who can be just a housewife because her husband is able to provide for the whole family. For now, they don’t have children but they are planning to have them in the near future. Her husband works as a taxi driver and provides for their family. Roza applied for a loan in order to buy gold jewelry: a gold ring and a pair of earrings. She expects to repay this loan with the her husband’s help. The other group members are: Mavlyuda A. is treasurer of the group. She is 48 and divorced. She raised her three children alone when her husband left her. Now, her elder son is 25, her elder daughter is 29 and her youngest daughter is 15. Her elder daughter is married, her son works in Russia and her youngest daughter goes to school. Fifteen years ago, Mavlyuda received some farmland and she decided to raise corn and cotton on it. She started with 700 soms and now it brings her 2,500 soms. With the profits from this she raised her children, married her daughter, and made capital repairs to her house. Mavlyuda is applying for a loan in order to buy necessary things to sow corn. This loan would help her business to continue functioning and she would be able to make profits again. With the profits received, Mavlyuda is planning to pay for her son’s marriage, make capital repairs to her house and give her daughter an opportunity to study. Dilmurot A. is 22 and single. He lives with his grandmother, uncle and sister. His grandmother is 72, his uncle is 35 and his sister is 19. His grandmother is a pensioner and receives a retirement allowance from the government; his uncle is a teacher at the local school and his sister looks after their house. Right now, Dilmurot works at a repair shop where he and his students repair refrigerators and other devices. He opened his own repair shop three years ago with initial investment of 2,000 soms. He came to this idea when he was a student at another repair shop. Now his income is 3,000 soms a month. In order to develop his business Dilmurot needs to buy motors for refrigerators. Therefore, he is applying for this loan. In the future, he is planning to expand his business, make capital repairs to his repair shop, and get married. Feruza T. is 26 and married with three children: her daughter is 8 and her sons are 6 and 2. Her daughter goes to school and her sons go to kindergarten. Her husband is a teacher of biology and chemistry at the local school. Feruza started her business by fattening a calf six years ago. From that moment on, she increased her head of cattle to one cow, one calf and three small cattle. She started her business with 7,000 soms and now makes 3,000 soms monthly. Now, Feruza is planning to buy more small cattle to increase the number of her cattle and, to realize her intent, she applied for this loan. With the profits from her business, she is planning to rebuild her old house, pay for her sons’ circumcision and expand her cattle breeding business. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a gold ring and a pair of earrings

loans.name: Chanthy's Group

texts.en:
Chanthy H., 48, is the village bank president having been selected by its twelve members which located in Preak Toch village, Kandal province. Each member will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.

Chanthy H. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living.  Her husband is a fisherman in the local village.  With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family.

In order to increase her income to improve her family's standard of living, Chanthy decided to ask for a loan to buy groceries to sell.  This couple has five children: two are iron welders; two are seamstresses in the garment factory and the other is a student.

loans.use: Buy groceries to  sell.

loans.name: Lois

texts.en:
Lois M., 28, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its quality palm products. M. and her husband are blacksmiths and are able to earn an income of USD 10 per day. M.'s husband appears in the photograph because M. was not available.

M. is requesting a loan of USD 1,100 to purchase more charcoal and metal to expand her current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and metal to expand her business

loans.name: André

texts.fr: R. André est un homme jeune marié de 29 ans, nés en district Kicukiro de la province de ville de Kigali Capital du Rwanda, son niveau d’étude est secondaire dans l’option électronique.  Il est commençant de détail en boutique des habits pour enfants. Il contracte un prêt pour  augmenter la quantité et la diversité des habits des enfants dans son boutique. Il a besoin d’acheter des petits robes et pantalons complets pour enfants. Il a ouvert un compte dans Amasezerano Community Banking   depuis mars 2010, avec ce prêt avec ambition et vision d’augmenter les épargnes afin de construire la maison d’habitation, l’augmentation de son chiffre d’affaires  lui permettra de faire vivre sa famille comme il faut et devenir grossiste dans l’avenir dans ce domaine de commerce des habits pour enfants.
texts.en:
R. André is a young married man, aged 29, who was born in the Kicukiro district in the province of the city of Kigali, capital of Rwanda.  He concentrated on electronics in his secondary education.  He is a retail merchant in a children's clothing store.  André signed a loan to increase the quantity and diversity of children's clothing in his store.  He needs to purchase small dresses and outfits with pants for children.  He opened an account with Amasezerano Community Banking in March 2010.  With this loan, and with ambition and vision, he will increase his savings in order to build a house.  The growth in his sales will enable him to provide for his family like he should and to become a wholesale merchant in the future in his business sector, children's clothing.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying dresses and outfits for children

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Phan S., 38, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its quality palm products. Her husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

S. and her husband are farmers and are able to earn an income of USD 2 each per day. She is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a motorbike for the family’s use.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's use

loans.name: Chynygul's Group

texts.en:
Chynygul M., leader of the group, is 24 and single. She works as an accountant at village administration. She needs a cell phone in order to communicate with her colleagues and relatives who are in different parts of Kyrgyzstan and outside of Kyrgyzstan. Unfortunately, she is not able to buy a cell phone due to absence of money. Therefore, she applied for a loan to buy a cell phone.

Group members: Nargiza A. is treasurer of the group. She is 24 and single. Like Chynygul, she works at village administration. She also needs a cell phone. She applied for a loan in order to buy a cell phone which will move her to a new level of communication with her relatives, friends, and colleagues. As she receives her wages, she will gradually repay her loan.

Kanatbek M. is 28 and married. He has two children, a four-year-old daughter and a two-year-old son. His wife is a housewife. Two years ago, he decided to start cattle breeding with an initial investment of 2,000 soms. For now, he receives 1,500 soms monthly, but he plans to increase the number of cattle and, as a result, increase profits from cattle breeding. Also, cattle breeding helped him to buy his car, a Daewoo Tico. In order to increase the number of cattle, he needs to buy more heads of cattle. Unfortunately, he doesn’t have enough funds. Thus, he is applying for a loan. With the profit from cattle breeding, he plans to increase the number of cattle.

Gulhan T. is 58 and married. She has five children. Her sons are 33 and 26, and her daughters are 37, 36, and 29. Her daughters are married and live independently. Her first son is a teacher at a college, and her second son is in Russia. Her husband is a pensioner, while she breeds cattle with the help of her first son. Six years ago she decided to buy a cow because, in her opinion, it was safer than just holding money. After that, she decided to breed cattle. Now, they have 25 heads of cattle, which they will fatten and sell. With the profit from cattle breeding, she could buy a car for her son and make capital repairs to her house. Starting her business with 2,000 soms, she now makes 20,000 soms monthly. She is applying for a loan in order to buy two goats, fatten them, and resell them in the future at a higher price. With the profit from cattle breeding, she plans to buy a truck for transportation of cattle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line—People (building human capital and taking care of customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstanat http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a mobile phone

loans.name: Liberathe

texts.en:
Liberathe is 30 years old, married with 5 children who are between 1 and 11 years old.  Liberathe is commonly known in the business of selling drinks made out of sorghum.  She has been in this business for about 10 years and the business hours are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Liberathe needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Liberathe will hopefully increase her sales as well as profits.  If successful, Liberathe will keep expanding her business and in addition to that, she will try to create some other sources of income and continue taking care of her family.

loans.use: A large quantity of sorghum to make drinks for sale

loans.name: Chanra's Group

texts.en:
Chanra U., 47, is the village bank president having been selected by its eleven members which located in Preak T. village, Kandal province.  With this loan, each member hopes to increase his or her income, to improve the living standard of their family.

Chanra is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living.  Her husband is a fisherman.  With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family.  Chanra will use the loan to buy a fishing machine for her husband.  This couple has three children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, another is a construction worker.  The third is a student.

loans.use: Buy fishing machine for fishing.

loans.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en: Day by day, women around the world become more independent. They either choose to be independent or are forced by circumstances. Anyway, we see a general trend that women provide for their families, become independent of their husbands and gradually move from lower positions to the positions of CEO, leaders of political parties, diplomats, deputies and even presidents. Aigul T., the leader of the group, is one of those women who were forced to start businesses in order to raise and feed their children after being divorced. She is 36 and has three children. Her elder son is 15 and her daughters are 13 and 3 years old. She doesn’t have a university degree from a top business school, but she found skills and the knowledge to earn money. She started her business by cooking pies, samsy and ashlyamfu (Kyrgyz traditional food) 12 years ago with an initial investment of 3,000 soms and each month she receives 10,000 soms as income. Now, her son and daughter go to school and the youngest daughter goes to kindergarten. With her children, she dreams to buy a big house. She already has accumulated a considerable amount of money. However, she cannot afford to buy the house of her and her children's dreams yet. Thus, Aigul decided to broaden the sphere of her business. She decided to buy school and office accessories in Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyz Republic) and then resell them at a higher price in her village (the Issykkul region of the Kyrgyz Republic). She is asking for a loan because she doesn’t have enough funds to realize the above described business idea. Group members: Gulbarchyn O. is treasurer of the group. She is 62 and a widow. Her children are grown up and live independently of their mother. She has a cattle-breeding business. The business was started three years ago with the initial investment of 8,000 soms and has a monthly income of 5,300 soms. She helped one of her children with the beginning of construction of a new house. Now she wants to help her son repair his truck. Thus, she is applying for this loan. Bakytbek K. is 35 and recently married. He was working in a dental clinic but due to the low salary, he decided to open his own dental clinic. He started his business five years ago with the initial investment of 2,000 soms. Now he receives 15,000 soms monthly. He is applying for a loan in order to buy necessary medicines. Maksatbek M. is 25 and married. He has a son who is 3 years old. He is a taxi driver in the military registration and enlistment office. His wife is a shop assistant. Still, their wages are not enough to live together and raise their 3-year-old child. Together with his wife, he started a bakery business one year ago with the initial investments of 500 soms. Their business brings them 9,100 soms monthly. They already have bought a boiler and they are applying for a loan in order to buy a microwave and flour. Together with his wife, they are planning to open a cafeteria. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3 Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase school and office accessories

loans.name: Jonilo

texts.en:
Jonilo A. is from the town of Talibon. He is 32 years old. Jonilo is married and has four children. To make a living, Jonilo operates a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market. Jonilo has been engaged in fishing for two years now. He plans to grow hogs for fattening and sale.

Jonilo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jonilo has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jonilo is requesting a new loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase a fishing boat. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo K., 38, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for high quality palm products. K. is a farmer and is able to earn an income of USD 1.50 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per day. K. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to provide a suitable wedding for one of the children.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: provide for a suitable wedding for her son

loans.name: Balqees

texts.en:
Balqees has been living in a small city in Punjab, Pakistan called Kot Radha Kishen for the last 25 years. Kot Radha Kishen is known for its dairy industry as most of the people live there have dairy businesses.  

Balqees’s husband also operates the same business as most of the people do here. He works in the wheat fields in the morning and in the evening he sells milk of his buffaloes. Currently, he has a buffalo at his house. Balqees also helps her husband in his business. She takes care of the buffalo when her husband works in the field. 

She is the mother of two daughters and two sons and lives with her family in a three-room brick house.  Three of her four children are getting their education and are in 6th, 3rd, and 2nd standard respectively while her eldest son left school after his 8th year and started driving. He drives a rickshaw to supplement the income of his family. 

Balqees has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s dairy business. With the loan amount her husband will buy another buffalo and increases the milk-production.  Balqees is confident that her husband will be able to make positive use of the loan money and increase his income by selling good quantity milk to his customers. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is on her 4th loan. She has maintained a good credit record in past loan years and has never missed any meeting.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for her husband's dairy business

loans.name: Koisun's Group

texts.en:
How can you give up if someone is expecting you to succeed? This was in the mind of Koisun T. eight years ago, when she started her business alone. After being divorced from her husband and receiving no help from him, she started considering options of starting up a business in order to provide for her two children. She started making pasties and selling them at the local market and shops with an initial investment of 1000 soms. Then she saved some money and started buying wholesale vegetables and selling them at the local market. Her business helped her to raise her children and give them an education. Now, Koisun is 45 and divorced. Her son is 20 and her daughter is 18. Also, she has bought a calf with the profits from her business to fatten it and sell it in the future at a higher price.    Her business brings her 8000 soms monthly. She is applying for a loan in order to continue her business, buying wholesale cabbages, peppers, and cucumbers and selling them at a higher price. With the profits from her business, she wants to give quality higher education to her daughter, help her son financially to get married, and buy a big house for her family.

Group members:
