Gulsora B. is treasurer of the group. She is 29 and married. She has three children. Her son is 11, one daughter is 9 and her younger daughter is 4. All of them go to school. Her husband earns a living by making capital repairs. Due to the absence of work opportunities, Gulsora decided to start her business by buying wholesale detergents in the capital of Kyrgyzstan and selling them at a higher price in her region. She started her business with an initial investment of 3000 soms. After a certain period of time, she decided to switch from selling detergents to vegetables because that promised higher profits. Now, her monthly income is 20,000 soms. With the profits from her business, Gulsora has been able to provide for members of her family and buy a cow. Now, she is applying for a loan in order to buy another cow and hay for her. She believes that another cow will increase her profits and then she could realize her plan to build a house and buy a car for her family. 

Nurbek T. is 39 and married. He has 3 children. His elder daughter is 15 and is studying in the US, his second daughter is 4 and his youngest child, a son is one month old. Two years ago, together with his wife, he started selling convenience goods right at their home with initial investments of 5000 soms. Then they decided to put a table next to their house and sell convenience goods there. After a time, with the profits from selling convenience goods, they decided to build a shop near their house. Also, the profits from the shop gave them an opportunity to buy goats to breed. From that moment, they have separated obligations: the shop was under the control of his wife and he focused on goat breeding. Right now, their business brings 13,000 soms monthly. They found an opportunity to increase their profits through increasing the assortment of goods at their shop. Thus, Nurbek is applying for loan to get necessary funds to diversify their assortment. At the same time, he wants to prepare for the winter season and buy one ton of coal. 

Raikan B. is 47 and a widow. She has three children. Her daughter is 19, one son is 15 and her younger son is 8. Her sons are studying in the US. Raikan finished courses as a hairdresser two years ago and decided to start her business by opening a hairdressing salon with an initial investment of 500 soms. She rents a place for her hairdressing salon where she works together with her daughter. Her salon brings her 8000 soms monthly. Now, her daughter is planning to get married. According to Kyrgyz traditions, the mother should provide a dowry for her daughter. Unfortunately, she doesn’t have enough money therefore she is applying for a loan which will help her to buy a dowry.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cabbages, peppers, and cucumbers

loans.name: Jeejaan

texts.en:
Jeejaan is the resident of a small city located in Punjab province of Pakistan called Kot Radha Kishen. She is a housewife but she also helps her son in his milk-selling business. She is the mother of three children. Her eldest son is involved in a dairy business and the other two work in private companies on monthly wage. Jeejaan has a single dairy cow at her house and she takes care of her with her son. 

She owns a three-room brick house in this city. She moved here after her marriage with S. P. 30 years ago. Her husband started the milk-selling business but now this business has shifted to his son as the father has grown old and can’t work. 

Jeejaan’s son wants to buy another buffalo because he wants to increase the quantity of his milk. That’s why Jeejaan has applied for a loan from Asasah.  She hopes that her son will be able to successfully upgrade his business by purchasing another buffalo and the living standard of her family will improve. Jeejaan is  a regular client of Asasah and is on her 3rd loan.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Celestin

texts.en:
Celestin is 28 years old, married with two children.  Celestin owns a shop where he sells a variety of goods and he has owned this shop for about two years.  His shop is open from 6 am until 8 pm every day.

Celestin is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  Once given this loan, Celestin will hopefully increase his sales as well as his profits.  In addition to that, he will start selling foodstuffs as they are highly demanded by a large number of his customers.  Celestin hopes for a better future in his business.

loans.use: A variety of goods to sell in his shop

loans.name: Nyakatukura Primary School, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Here in Uganda, M. Robert has banked his savings in running a shop to get more profit. The married father of 4 started up a grocery store dealing in dry foods especially cereals 6 years ago in Nyakatukura, Ibanda. Due to hard work and determination, he has been able to run this business successfully and it earns him 200,000 Ugandan shillings monthly. 

With this loan he is looking forward to restocking the business with more millet and beans which will make him popular in the market and attract many customers to his shop. Earning more revenue and making the business expand is his main motive, so as to have a self-sustaining livelihood as he looks forward to educating his children. Robert is also a teacher by profession, working at Nyakatukura Primary school, and his monthly salary contributes to his income.

loans.use: purchase  more inventory

loans.name: Muth

texts.en:
Muth C., 47, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. C. raises pigs at home for an income of USD 1.50 per day. Her husband produces cement pipes, earning an income of USD 3 per day.

 C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a plot of farmland to produce more rice to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Ork

texts.en:
Ork A. is a 50-year-old resident of Kompong Tom Province. To earn a living, Ork sells cakes to village neighbors that she makes from her home.  She earns about $1.50 a day.  

She is married to a taxi driver and they have six children, two of whom are married.  Three of their children are employed: one daughter is a garment worker, another sells vegetable.  Their son works in construction.  The family always cultivates a rice crop during the rainy season.  Ork is requesting a loan to buy and raise a cow to be used to plow her farmland.

loans.use: Buy a cow.

loans.name: Sophy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophy S., age 46, is the village bank president. She was selected by the group's thirteen members, located in Taen village, Kandal province. The members of this village loan will use the money to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.     
Mrs. Sophy S. is a widow who owns 2-hectares of land that she uses to cultivate rice for a living. She is a farmer who works very hard to support her two children. In order to support this farm, she will use the loan that she has requested from AMK to buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Muhabbathon's Group

texts.en:
Muhabbathon H. is the leader of this group. She is 37 and married. She has three children. Her eldest son is 23, her second son is 14, and the youngest son is 11. Her eldest son is a student and the second and the youngest son go to school. Her husband is a tractor driver. 25 years ago, her husband offered to start livestock breeding business in order to earn extra money. She liked that idea and assigned 3000 soms from the family budget for purchase of livestock. Now her livestock breeding business has functioned successfully for almost 25 years and it brings in 10,000 soms monthly. With the profits from the business, she bought a car for her husband and the whole family. In order to continue breeding livestock she needs 100 kilogram of forage for her animals and also she wants to buy one more sheep in order to increase the number of livestock she has. Unfortunately, she doesn’t have sufficient funds, therefore she is applying for a loan. 

Group members:

Mamlakat H. is treasurer of the group. She is 31 and married. She has 3 children. Her elder son is 10, her second son is 8 and her daughter is 2. Her sons go to school and her daughter is still at home. Her husband is a master in a service center. She works as a distributor of medicines but her main activity is cattle breeding. She started her cattle breeding business 10 years ago. Once, on the birthday of her son, relatives made a generous present for her child and Mamlakat decided to use that present as a start for her business. After starting her business with 3000 soms, now she gets 5000 soms monthly from cattle breeding. With the profits from cattle breeding, she has already made capital repairs at her house and bought a car for her husband. In order to continue the successful functioning of her business, she is applying for loan which will give her an opportunity to buy two head of cattle to fatten and sell. 

Sapar N. is 68 and married. His wife is housewife. He has two children. His son is 36 and his daughter is 33. Both of them are working in Russia. Children here actively support their parents in all ways and especially financially. Nurdin in his turn, breeds cattle. He inherited cattle breeding from his parents, because they also bred cattle. He has been 40 years in the cattle breeding business which he started with initial investments only of 400 soms. Now, it brings him in 8000 soms monthly. He is applying for loan with the purpose of buying 2 head of cattle to fatten and sell at a higher price. 

Abdubahap E. is 28 and married. His wife is a housewife and helps her husband in his business. For now they don’t have any children. Abdubahap started breeding cattle 15 years ago with an initial investment of 4000 soms. Now, he has been able to increase the number of heads to 2 cows with one calf and 6 head of small livestock; cattle breeding brings in 7000 soms monthly. He is applying for a loan in order to buy 6 more head of livestock to fatten and sell at a higher price. In the near future, he is planning to further increase the number of livestock in his herd and make capital repairs to his house with the profits from his business. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase 100 kilograms of forage and one sheep

loans.name: Mehwish

texts.en:
Mehwish is 24 years old and married 30-year-old A. A. about two years ago. She moved to Kot Radha Kishen after her marriage, a small city in Pakistan located in Punjab province and famous for its dairy products. She lives in a small village near a city called Gandhian Outad in a three-room brick house with her family. She doesn’t have any children as she just got married two years ago. 

Her husband is an educated person. He continued his education up to 10th standard and started to work in the wheat fields to support the family financially. In the morning he works in the wheat fields and in the evening he sells milk from his buffalo.  He has been involved in a milk-selling business for the last 10 years. 

Mehwish is a housewife. In the absence of her husband she takes care of the buffalo and gives her water and food on time. Her husband wants to buy another buffalo for his business so he can sell milk to more people and generate good income. Mehwish has applied for a loan from Asasah to buy a buffalo for her husband’s business. She is hopeful that by purchasing another buffalo, her husband will be able to get the desired positive results from his business. She is a regular client of Asasah and is on her 2nd loan.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Lung

texts.en: Lung L., 47, is widowed and resides with her three children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. L. is a farmer and is able to earn an income of USD 2 per day. One of her children is employed at a local construction factory, earning an income of USD 3 per day. L. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to finish building her son's house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to buy more plots of farmland.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. L. appears in the photograph with her son.

loans.use: finish building her son's house

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long R., 63, a dessert seller. She is a single mother of five children: two are single and the rest are married. Four of her children are working in different occupations (two are garment workers, one works for a publishing company, and another is a rice farmer). As their vehicle is getting old and breaks down frequently, Long R. and her children face difficulties traveling to work or anywhere else. She is requesting a loan in order to replace her old motorcycle.

loans.use: To replace her old motorcycle.

loans.name: Okasana's Group

texts.en:
Okasana S., the leader of this group, is 24 and married. She has two daughters, 6 and 4 years old. Okasana and her husband are farmers, but her husband works as a builder when there is an opportunity. Right after their marriage, her husband suggested breeding cattle. They started breeding cattle together 2 years ago with an initial investment of 10,000 soms. With the help of profits from cattle breeding they improved their living conditions significantly. Now, they receive 1500 soms a month as a profit from cattle breeding and in order to increase their profits they want to buy farm animals. With money received from the loan Okasana wants to purchase two farm animals and hay to feed them during the winter season. This loan would help them increase their profits and provide better living conditions for their two little daughters. 

Group members:

Shaiyr O. is treasurer of the group. She is 60 and married. She has a daughter who is 20. Her daughter works as a seamstress. Her husband is farmer and Shaiyr has been  breeding cattle for almost 2 years. She started breeding cattle with an initial investment of 2500 soms. Now, she makes 1500 soms monthly from cattle breeding. In order to increase her profits, she's planning to buy 4 more ewes, then fatten and sell them at a higher price. She already has educated her daughter about the profits from cattle breeding. Now, she wants to prepare a dowry for her daughter, also from the profits from cattle breeding. 

Ulan O. is 35 and married. He has two sons, 9 and 8 years old.   Both of his sons go to school. His wife is a seamstress. Ulan in his turn combines cattle breeding with a job as a taxi driver in order to provide for members of his family. He has been in the cattle breeding business for two years; he started with initial investments of 20,000 soms. Now, it brings him 2000 soms monthly. Like other group members, in order to increase his profits from cattle breeding, he needs more head of cattle. So, this is the first reason for his application for a loan. The second reason is that he needs to make car repairs so as to continue his job as a taxi driver. With the profit from a loan, he is planning to increase significantly the number of head of livestock he has and buy a flat in the capital of Kyrgyzstan (Bishkek) where his children can enjoy better educational opportunities. 

Almazbek O. is 40 and married. He has two daughters, 6 and 4 years old. His wife is a teacher of the Kyrgyz language at a local school. Almazbek as well as Ulan has to combine his job as an engineer with agriculture in order to provide for members of his family. 7 years ago, he received as a present from his parents an area under cultivation, which pushed him to start sowing potatoes and wheat. He started sowing potatoes and wheat with initial investments of 3000 soms. Profit from agriculture provided for his family and improved the living conditions of his family. Besides this, he bought furniture for his house. His profit from agriculture is 1500 soms per month. Now, he wants to start cattle breeding. In order to start cattle breeding, he needs to buy at least one head of cattle. Thus, he is applying for a loan. This loan will help him to buy one head of cattle and forage for cattle. He believes that he will increase significantly his herd. On the received profits, he wants to make capital repairs on his house and provide better living conditions for his family. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase hay and two farm animals

loans.name: Eang

texts.en: Eang M., 42, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. M. is a farmer and is able to earn an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per day. M. is requesting a loan of USD 250 to repair her house. In the future, she would like to buy a new motorbike for her husband so he can operate his business efficiently.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. M.'s husband appears in the photograph because M. was not available.

loans.use: repair the house

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en:
Sajida has applied for a loan for the 4th time from Asasah to financially support her husband in his dairy business. She lives in a four-room brick house with her family in a small city, Kot Radha Kishen, which is located in Punjab, Pakistan. She is the mother of 2 sons and 2 daughters. All of them are getting their education. Her daughters read in 5th and 4th standard while sons are in 2nd and in kindergarten. 

Sajida is 39 years old and married to M. A.. She is a housewife who stays at home doing her household chores but she offers full support to her husband. She takes care of the buffaloes in his absence. 

Her husband has been in the dairy business for the past 30 years and has a lot of experience in the dairy industry. Currently, he has three buffaloes at his home and wants to buy another one to increase the milk-production of his business. Sajida is hopeful that her husband will be able to make positive changes to his business by investing the loan money in it.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for their dairy business

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean de Dieu is 32 years old and he is married.  Jean de Dieu is commonly known in the business of selling clothes and he has been in this business for about 5 years. The hours of his business are from 8 am to 6 pm every day.

 After realizing that his capital is still too low to expand meaningfully, Jean de Dieu decided he needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, he will purchase different styles of clothes to sell which in turn will increase his sales as well as profits.  If successful, he will create some other sources of income and create more jobs to the people from his community.

loans.use: Different styles of clothes for sale

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima T., the leader of this group, is 58 and married. She has three sons and a daughter of 18 who is a student.  Fatima and her husband are pensioners. In 1988, Fatima’s farther gave her and her husband one head of cattle, 8 goats, and 5 sheep as a present for their marriage. She decided to start breeding cattle and increase the number of heads of cattle. With the profits from successful cattle breeding, she built a house, married off her two sons, and bought a flat in the capital of Kyrgyzstan (Bishkek). Her profit from cattle breeding is 20,000 per month. She is applying for a loan to build a fence around her house. She will repay the loan with the help of profits received in the future from cattle breeding. This autumn, she is planning to marry off her third son. 

Group members:

Parida I. is treasurer of the group. She is 54 and married. She has 4 children. Her elder son is 21, her first daughter is 18, her second daughter is 15 and her youngest daughter is 12.   Her son is going to graduate this year from Tashkumyr Institute and he combines his studying process with a job as a road worker. Her first daughter is a junior at the Tashkumyr College. In 2002, they made 20,000 som on the resale of coal and used this money for a purchase of one head of cattle and 7 goats. Starting their business with 20,000, they make  8000 som each month. Cattle breeding is mainly the job of Paridas' husband. At present, they have been able to increase their livestock herds to 4 cows, 4 calves, 100 goats and 10 sheep. They applying for a loan in order to buy 7 or 8 sheep to fatten and sell at a higher price.  In the future, with the profits from cattle breeding, they are planning to open a food store and to buy a car for the family.

Azamat R. is 20 and single. He lives with his mother, farther, and two sisters. His little sister is 15 and goes to school. His elder sister is a teacher at the local school. His mother works in Russia. Azamat works in coal during the appropriate season, works as a builder with his farther during the summer period and breeds cattle. During the summer periods when Azamat and his father work as builders, their cattle are under the care of his grandparents on his mother’s side. With the efforts of his grandparents, Azamat has been able to increase the number of livestock in his herd to 4 head of cattle and 16 sheep. Azamat started cattle breeding 4 years ago with an initial investment of 5000 som. Now, this brings in  500 soms monthly. Azamat applied for a loan in order to get funds to rebuild his old cattle shed. With the profits from cattle breeding, Azamat is planning to build his own house and  after that, get married and live a happy married life with his beloved wife.
 
Ernes B. is 26 and married. He has a son  one year old. His wife is a housewife. He is a taxi driver on the road between Jalalabat – Karakul with his own car. Each day he earns 600 som. Besides being a taxi driver, Ernes earns money with cattle breeding. Two years ago, he bought one goat for 750 som. Since that moment, he has increased the number of goats to 4. During summer periods, his wife’s parents take care of their cattle in the mountains where there are better conditions for goats. During winter periods, Ernes breeds goats himself. Now, livestock breeding brings him in 15,000 som monthly. He wants to increase the number of livestock he has. Thus, he is applying for a loan in order to buy more 10 goats. He will fatten them and sell them at a higher price. In the future, with the profits from livestock breeding, he wishes to buy his own house, because now he lives with his parents. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to build a fence around the house

loans.name: Bushenyi Women Tuhumurizane Group

texts.en:
They say hard work pays, and a very determined T. Regina has gained from the fruits of her hard work, having started up her cooked food enterprise over 11 years ago, offering catering services in Bushenyi town. She has no regrets.

Due to good management and esteemed customer care, the business has maintained customers for a long time, thus creating a good market as she maintains high levels of hygiene. Most of her customers are town dwellers. With this loan, Regina wants to put in place good furniture and also go shopping for restaurant equipment as she looks at improving the quality of her catering services. This will enable her to get more customers, earn more profit and be able to cover her family and children’s requirements such as education. She is very optimistic about achieving a self-sustaining livelihood with more income coming her way.

loans.use: new furniture and improving the quality of her catering service

loans.name: Khat

texts.en: Khat C., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. C. sells groceries for an income of USD 1.50 per day. Her husband is a cameraman, earning an income of USD 2 per day. C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to buy a motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her current business.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. C.'s husband appears in the photograph because C. was not available.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the family to use

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mr. Keo M. has been earning a living for many years by climbing the palm trees behind his house. Palm-tree-climbing jobs are very common for poor people who live in a rural commune. Keo M. has a plot of farming land where he and his wife farm rice crops during the coming rainy season. This couple are the good parents of five teenage kids, two of whom are employed. Keo M. requests a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizer and seed for planting. (Mr. Keo M.’s wife is pictured.)

loans.use: purchasing fertilizer and seed

loans.name: Zipora

texts.en:
Zipora is 34 years old and is married with six children between 2 and 12 years old. She is well-known in the business of selling sorghum. She has been in this business for about two years and the business hours are from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. every day.

Zipora needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her business through purchasing a large quantity of sorghum. This will increase her profits. With these profits, she will create more sources of income by selling different goods.

If successful, Zipora will start saving for a better future and continue improving the living style of her family.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of sorghum to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen A. is from the town of Talibon. She is 31 years old. Helen is married and has six school-aged children. Helen owns and operates a weaving business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling yantok mats & mattresses to tourists and local community members. Helen's husband is a fisherman and she also helps him sell his catch. 

Helen joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Helen is requesting a new loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to expand the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Helen from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: business expansion

loans.name: Nul

texts.en: Nul E., 36, is married and resides with her husband and six children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. E. sells animal food for an income of $20 US per day. Her husband is a famer, earning an income of $5 per day. E. is requesting a loan of $800 to buy a sewing machine to start a new business at the market. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her current business of selling animal food.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. E. appears in the photograph with her daughter.

loans.use: buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Biyinzika Kabyuma Group, Mubende

texts.en:
T. Justus is a 38-year-old happily married father of 3 school-going children who has been running a salon business for 10 years in Kibyamirizi, Mubende. With all his efforts, he has been able to maintain it earning him 200,000 Ugandan shillings. This income has always been significant in contributing towards his family's welfare. 

His current setback is lacking additional capital for purchasing salon materials like: hair cutting machines, shampoo, hair oils, and a drier, basically demanded by lady customers. Therefore this loan will help Justus in restocking his business. He is very interested in what he does and he is grateful that he chose the salon as his business.

loans.use: beauty salon equipment and supplies

loans.name: Svay

texts.en: Mrs. Svay H., age 28, owns and operates a handicraft business in which the main activity is selling rattan cupboard. She sells rattan that her husband weaves or that she orders from other weavers who live in the village. She uses her horse cart as transportation and takes it each week to sell all her rattan. In addition to their rattan business, Svay H. owns a piece of farmland where she and her husband raise rice crops. Growing rice is an annual activity with which they have had great success. Svay H. is humbly requesting a loan to use towards planting crops during the approaching rainfall season.

loans.use: To use towards planting crops during the approaching rainfall season.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 36 years old and is married with five children who are between 6 and 13 years old.

Esther sells drinks made from sorghum and she has been in this business for a long time. The hours of her business are from 8 a.m. until late in the evening hours.

Esther needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase a large quantity of sorghum for making drinks to sell to her customers. If successful, Esther will keep expanding her business and create some other sources of income and more jobs for the people in her community.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of sorghum for making drinks to sell

loans.name: Mairo Mbili Group C-Jinja

texts.en: 42-year-old K. Fred has been a hard-working taxi driver for the last 15 years. This has been his main source of income since then. He was at first a fuel pump attendant. His close friend introduced him to this business. In a week, he makes 40,000 shillings. Proceeds from this loan he says will help him pay his three children’s school fees more often.

loans.use: paying children's school fees

loans.name: Sameeh

texts.en:
Sameeh is a young man from Ramallah city. He wasn't fortunate enough to continue his education, so Sameeh's parents helped him start making a living and taking responsibility by renting a grocery store. The store is becoming well known in the neighborhood and is attracting a lot of customers.

Sameeh took a $3,000 loan from FATEN in response to an increase in the number of customers.  He needs to purchase a larger amount of goods to answer the demand. Sameeh is very happy that now he is able to take care of his own expenses and that he has his own business.

Sameeh appears in his store in the picture above.

loans.use: To purchase extra inventory

loans.name: Saro's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Saro P., age 48, is the village bank president, having been selected by its twenT.-four members located in Ampov Prey Pir village, Kandal province. The members of this village loan will use the money to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Saro P. is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice for a living. In order to support this farm, she will use the loan that she has requested from AMK to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for laborers to plow her farm to cultivate rice. Mrs. Saro Phanm is a widow with three children: One is a knitter and the other two are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for laborers to plow her farm to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Najma

texts.en:
Najma lives in a small city called Kasur. It is located in Punjab near Lahore Pakistan and famous for its leather industry. She lives in a three room brick house with her family. She moved here after her marriage with M. A. who has been in the milk selling business for the last 20 years. For this purpose he has kept three buffalos at his home. 

Najma is the mother of a daughter who is just 2 years old and has not started to attend school yet. She is a housewife but she also helps her husband in his business by taking care of his buffalos. She offers full support to her husband in his business. 

She has acquired a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan he will buy another buffalo to increase the production of milk and to increase his income.  Najma is very much sure that her husband will be able to increase his income by increasing the milk-productivity from the new buffalo. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her third loan cycle.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose T. is currently in the business of selling exercise books, text books, pens, etc. in a book shop and is requesting a loan to stock boxes of chalk, more exercise books, and boxes of pencils to sell.  Rose is 37 years old and is married with a husband that is a pastor. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a permanent house.

loans.use: Stock boxes of chalks, more exercise books and boxes of pencils to sell

loans.name: Flora

texts.en: Flora S. is currently in the business of selling sugar, charcoal, cooking oil, fish and rice at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and jerrycans of cooking oil to sell.  Flora is 36 years old and is married with a husband that is a government worker. She has six children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a permanent house for rent.

loans.use: stocking rice and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Eou

texts.en: Eou P., 50, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. P. is a farmer and is able to earn an income of $4 US per day. Her husband is a taxi-driver, earning an income of $10 per day. P. is requesting a loan of $700 to change to a new car for her husband to operate his business efficiently. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buying a car to be used as a taxi

loans.name: Kosar

texts.en:
Kosar is 42 years old and lives in Kasur, which is a small city located near Lahore Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its leather industry. She moved into a three room brick house here after her marriage with S. A.. She is the mother of three sons and a daughter. Only her eldest son is able to attend school and is studying in 2nd standard. 

Her husband and she have both been operating a milk selling business for the last 10 years. S.’s father shifted his business to him after he grew old. Now he is operating this business very well.  He has a vast space available for keeping buffalos at his house.  He wants to improve his milk selling business by buying another buffalo.  

Kosar has applied for a loan from Asasah which will be used by her husband in purchasing another buffalo. Kosar hopes that her husband will be able to increase his income by selling a larger quantity of milk. Kosar remains concerned about the fact that she is not able to send her younger children to school but she is hopeful that with increased income she will soon be in a position to provide education to her remaining children also. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her 3rd loan cycle.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Talvesuin Afghian Group

texts.en:
Khadeja is a member of Talvesuin Afghian group. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan, in a household of nine members.

Khadeja is tailor and sews all kinds of clothes. She needs the loan to purchase a sewing machine plus other essential materials such as different kinds and colors of thread, small and big sizes of scissors and so on. She is glad that though this loan process she can develop her business.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine, different kinds and colors of thread, large and small scissors, etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary D. is currently in the business of selling cooking oil, rice, charcoal, dried fish, beans and simsim (sesame seed) and is requesting a loan to stock bags of groundnuts (peanuts) and sorghum to sell.

Mary is 46 years old and is widowed. She has seven children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To stock bags of groundnuts and sorghum to sell

loans.name: Theoun's Group

texts.en:
Four people are making up a group loan. Mrs. Theoun C. is a 23 years old married woman and is the group leader of the loan, having been selected by its four members. They are located in Pou Ta Pang village, Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.   

Mrs. Theoun C. and her husband, Mrs. Soveit Chamroeun, are farming laborers in the local village who are able to receive a small salary to support their family. This couple has a child who is too young to study or work. Now their house is in disrepair, so, Mrs. Theoun C. has decided to ask for a loan from AMK to buy timber to fix up her house.

loans.use: To buy timbers to fix up her house.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok N., 40, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its quality palm products.

N. sells fish, earning an income of USD 12.50 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3.30 per day.

N. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to buy a new motorbike to enable her husband to operate his business efficiently. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

This is N.’s first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for her husband's business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes J. is currently in the business of selling fish and charcoal near her home and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans, rice and tomatoes to sell.  Agnes is 41 years old and is married to a peasant. She has seven children and four of them go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy sheep and goats to raise.

loans.use: Stock bags of beans, rice and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Begum

texts.en:
Begum is a resident of Kasur, which is a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and famous for its dairy and leather industries. She is 28 years old, married to H. A. S., and the mother of a son and a daughter, both of whom are very young.

Her husband has a business of selling milk. He sells the milk of his two buffalo. He wakes up early in the morning, gets milk from them and transfers the milk to milk jars. Then he transfers the milk jars to his motorbike and delivers them to different milk shops and to his community. He has been operating this business for the last ten years and is doing very well. Begum’s father-in-law has a shop where he sells cattle feed. He earns a reasonable amount of income every month. 

Begum has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan he will buy another buffalo for his milk-selling business. She hopes that by utilizing the money in this way, he will be able to expand his business and increase his income. 

Begum wants to give a quality education to her children once they become old enough to attend school. She is hopeful that her husband’s income will  increase enough that she will not face any problems in sending her children to school and affording their school fees.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for the dairy business

loans.name: Hairihon's Group

texts.en:
Hairihon K., the leader of this group, is 55 years old and married. She has a son who is 33 years old and works in a nonferrous metal working mine. Her husband is a farmer. Twenty years ago, she decided to buy and resell ice cream and make profit on it. She invested 2,000 KGS that time and now she makes about $135 monthly. In order to continue her business, she needs to buy more ice cream to resell. With the profits from her business, she wants to help her son to build a house in the future. 

Group members:
Mairam P., treasurer of the group, is 44 years old and married. She has a daughter who is 20. Her daughter helps her keep their house. Her husband is in Russia. When her husband started sending her money, she decided to buy convenience goods wholesale and resell them in order not to waste her husband’s money.  During weekends her daughter helps her. With the profits from selling convenience goods, she made capital repairs on her flat. Starting her business with 5,000 KGS seven years ago, she now makes about $130 monthly. She applied for a loan in order to buy 100 kilograms of macaroni, sugar and ten boxes of cookies and sweets. That purchase would help her to expand her business and increase her profits. 

Inabat A. is 52 years old and a widow. She has three sons who are 20, 16 and 7 years old.  Her eldest son is a freshmen at an institution of higher education and her next two sons go to school. She works as a nurse in the hospital. Now she needs to prepare her children for the academic year by buying school accessories and clothes for them. The only dream of Inabat is to educate her children. 

Pazilet D. is 55 years old and married. She has eight children. Her sons are 37, 34, 33, 32, 29, 28 and 22, and her daughter is 21. Her husband is an electrician. All her children, except for her youngest son, live independently and work either in a military unit or in Russia. She is applying for a loan in order to buy herself gold accessories. She is planning to repay this loan with the help of her children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only micro-finance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a vdeo presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase ice cream to resell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buy a tailoring table. fabric and other materials

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary S. is currently in the business of baking and selling local Sudanese bread (legemat & tamia)  and is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour and cooking oil to sell.  Mary is 36 years old and married to a farmer. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more baking flour and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Chum T., 54, is widowed and resides with her three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its quality palm products. She appears in the photograph with her daughter.

T. is employed as a construction worker for an income of USD 2.50 per day. Her daughter is a garment factory worker, earning an income of USD 2.50 per day.

T. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to buy a new motorbike for the family’s use. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's use

loans.name: Rani

texts.en:
Rani has applied for a loan for the expansion of her son’s milk-selling business. With the help of the loan, her son will buy another buffalo which will help him increase his sales and income.

Rani is a 55-year-old lady who has been living with her husband and family in a three-room brick house in Kasur, Pakistan, for the last thirty years. She is the mother of three children; unfortunately none of them could get an education. Her eldest son has taken over his father’s business of selling milk due to his growing old. Her second son drives a horse and cart and her daughter stays at home and manages the household chores with Rani.

Rani hopes that by using the loan to purchase a new buffalo, her son will be able to increase his profits. Milk selling is Rani’s family business and she is confident that it will be improved with this investment and she will be able to save money from the profits for the marriage of her only daughter who is now 17 years of age.

Rani is a regular loan user and is on her 3rd loan. In her previous loans she paid her installments on time and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: To enable her son to purchase another buffalo for the family dairy business

loans.name: Kheav

texts.en:
Mrs. Kheav Y., 33, is married to Noeun, 29, and they are wooden bed makers. This couple sometimes goes through the village buying wood from the forest people and taking it home to start turning it into beds. After they finish making them, the family transports the beds to sell them door-to-door around their community. They also buy more beds from other makers to resell.

Recently, Kheav Y. got orders for a lot of beds from her valued customers but she doesn’t have enough beds to serve them. As she doesn’t have sufficient capital, she decided to look for financial assistance to be used to order more wooden beds to fulfill the requirements of her customers.

loans.use: To order more wooden beds to fulfill the requirements of her customers

loans.name: Sonya

texts.en:
Sonya is a resident of Kasur which is a small city in Pakistan. It is located in Punjab province and is famous for its leather industry.

Sonya is 28 years old and is a seamstress. She supports her family by sewing clothes for her neighborhood clients. She is married to M. F. and is the mother of three daughters and a son. Currently she is not able to send her children to school but she’s hopeful that, with increased income, she will be able to provide education facilities for her children very soon. 

Sonya’s husband has a milk-selling business. He operates his business from his home and has been doing this for the last six years. Sonya has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount he will buy another buffalo to expand his milk-selling business. Sonya is hopeful that her husband will utilize the loan money in a proper way and will be able to get positive results from his business.

Sonya is one of Asasah’s regular loan users and is on her 2nd loan. With her previous loan she proved that she is very responsible, always paying her installments on time and never missing any meeting.

loans.use: To enable her husband to purchase another buffalo for his dairy business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace S. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, simsim (sesame seed) and onions at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of simsim to sell.

Grace is 50 years old and is married to a watchman. She has seven children and three of them go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To stock more bags of simsim to sell

loans.name: Snooky

texts.en:
This is Snooky T., 38, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Alfredo T., an entrepreneur, and is the mother of a kid of elementary school age. By the grace of God, Snooky has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Snooky; she, herself, has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Snooky operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages, piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 pesos-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. The owner earns an income by buying supplies wholesale and selling retail in small quantities.

Aside from the usual products, Snooky also managed to incorporate local snacks like her popular breakfast fare into her business. Morning commuters and early risers flock to her store to buy some champorado (native chocolate rice porridge), lugaw (savory chicken, egg and tripe rice porridge), sweet spaghetti, pansit (soy noodles) and similar items. Snooky’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Snooky is requesting a Php 21,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She will also invest some of the loan in buying raw ingredients for her breakfast fare. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Snooky dreams of being able to give her child a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to someday have her own stall where she can sell her products. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her work.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to sell plus raw ingredients for her breakfast fare

loans.name: Ork

texts.en:
Mr. Ork S. is an older man whose wife appears in the photograph. He is highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses from which he earns a living. Another earner is his wife, who works planting crops on their own farmland. They have three teenage kids, two of whom are employed and another one is a secondary student.

Ork S. has requested a loan for his wife use to buy fertilizer to improve her crops that are not growing well.

loans.use: To enable his wife to buy fertilizer to improve her crops

loans.name: Ganbold

texts.en:
Ganbold A. is 32 years old and lives with his wife in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

Ganbold operates a retail meat business in his town. He began his business in 2007 with the help of his wife at a local food market and after several years of operation, he has managed to establish himself in the business community. Ganbold purchases stock from the neighboring sub-provinces and resells it at a local market at retail prices. He seems good at his business accounting and wishes to expand his business by buying more livestock at wholesale prices. 

Ganbold is requesting a 1,500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase a number of livestock to slaughter, which he will use for his meat business.

loans.use: To purchase a number of livestock

loans.name: Onjima

texts.en: Onjima C. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables, fish, beans and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more dried fish and bags of beans to sell.  Onjima is 46 years old and is widowed.   She has 6 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent shop.

loans.use: Stock more dried fish and bags of beans to sell

loans.name: Realiza

texts.en:
This is Realiza G., 38, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Romeo G., a carpenter, and mother of two children, one of whom are already in elementary while the youngest, just barely able to toddle around, is the apple of Realiza and Romeo’s eyes. By the grace of God, Realiza has managed to support her older child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send both of her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Realiza, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Realiza operates a meat shop. Live pigs are bought from hog raisers and then slaughtered and sold to the immediate community. She has many patrons who buy the cut meat and then sell it at their respective market stalls. There are many patrons who prefer Realiza’s products since they are assured of its freshness and cleanliness. It is also a little cheaper to buy meat from an independent meat shop than the ones in the marker who sometimes use the services of professional slaughter houses for their meat. The cost of slaughter is added to the final price of the cut meat, and passed along to the customers. Thus, Realiza has many patrons who regularly anticipate her meat. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 16,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy live pigs to be slaughtered and sold every day. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Realiza dreams of being able to give both her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have her own market stall someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy live pigs to be slaughtered and sold every day

loans.name: Zahra

texts.en:
Zahra is a resident of Kasur which is located in Punjab province, Pakistan and is well known for its leather industries. She lives in a three-room brick house with her family in the area of Rehman-Pura which is a small district of Kasur. She is 31 years old, a mother of six children. She managed to provide education to only two of her children due to financial reasons. 

Her husband has an animal-selling business. He purchases animals (goats and cows) young, raises them and sells them at a higher price. He has been doing this business for the last 15 years. Zahra also supports her family financially by selling milk. She gets milk from her two buffaloes and sells their milk to her community. She operates her business from her home and earns a good income every month. 

Zahra has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy goats for his animal-selling business. EID (the Muslim holiday which comes after Ramadan) is near and her husband can earn big profits by selling animals then.  Zahra is hopeful that this investment will be profitable for her husband’s business.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her 4th loan.

loans.use: Purchase goats for animal-selling business

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en:
Angelique was born in 1981 and is single. She takes care of two dependents; the first is 19 and the second is one year old. These dependents are relatives. In the family of Angelique there is one member who works as technician.  Angelique owns a small business selling various products such as: soft drinks, cosmetics, biscuits, and so on.  This is her 2nd year of successful operation in business. The hours of her daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day.  She employs one person from her community as a helper so that her business runs well.

Angelique is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing an additional products for her store. This expansion will allow her to attract more customers which will make her more effective and more efficient.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Orn

texts.en: Orn V., 47, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. V. sell food at home for an income of USD 11 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 4 per day. V. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to buy a new motorbike for her daughter to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. V.'s husband appears in the photograph because V. was not available.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the daughter to commute to work

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more good-quality cosmetics

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary S. has a shop selling a variety of goods including sugar and salt. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and cartons of salt to sell.  Mary is 20 years old with a husband who is a businessman. She has two children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bar and stock crates of beer to sell.

loans.use: Stock more bags of sugar and cartons of salt to sell

loans.name: Ramzi

texts.en: Ramzi is 46, married, and the father of four children. He has sold clothes for eight years. He doesn’t have a shop but uses his car to visit several villages each day to sell as much as he can because he believes that a person must hunt for clients. Competition is very strong which is why Ramzi does not wait for clients to come to him. His honesty, good reputation, and good-quality products keep his clients loyal. This is Ramzi’s sixth cycle with Al Majmoua, which attests to his being a man in very good standing. Every time he requests a loan from Al Majmoua, he increases his capital, as he will do this time. Ramzi hopes to improve his business in many ways -- through wholesale and improving quality.

loans.use: To increase his capital

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita G., 50, who lives in Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Ediom G. and they have five children ranging from a college whiz to an elementary-school youngster. By the grace of God, Nenita has managed to support her older child's college education. She is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Nenita is a college education, as she herself has. She believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Nenita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Juanita's profit comes from buying supplies wholesale and selling in piece rate. Aside from the usual products, Nenita also managed to incorporate meats and cooked food, like her popular lunch and dinner fare, into her business. Commuters, students, and people who don't cook at home, flock to her store to buy adobo (soy chicken or pork), menudo (liver and pork cutlets in a rich tomato sauce with carrots and potatoes), sisig (liver, ear, and other face meat of a pig, grilled then chopped and tossed in vinegar, chili and a little mayonnaise). Nenita’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a minimum of Php3500 in sales every day.

Nenita is requesting a Php18,000 loan to buy more groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her inventory. She also will invest some of the loan to buy raw ingredients for her lunch and dinner fare. She expects to boost her income as she expands her business.
  
Nenita dreams of being able to give her children a high-quality education through all her hard work. She also hopes to have her own stall where she could sell her products someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to expand her inventory and to buy raw ingredients for her lunch and dinner fare

loans.name: Chhourn

texts.en: Chhourn S., 27, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia -- an area known for quality palm products. S. is a housewife while her husband is a taxi driver, earning an income of USD 25 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to buy a new car for her husband's business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new car

loans.name: Ramzi

texts.en:
Ramzi is a 32-year-old single man and owner of a household goods store for the past 8 years. Ramzi sells many useful things in his shop such as gifts, antiques and decorative things. He has been using micro-credit through Al Majmoua since 2007, and he’s totally convinced of its procedures. He used these loans to increase his capital and it was obvious to everyone that his work was expanding. His experience in this field of work gave him a positive point to improve his work constantly. 

Ramzi is requesting a loan for the same reason this time: in order to buy different new collections for his business. He’s always working on improving and developing his inventory.

loans.use: To buy new collections

loans.name: Hausilagzam

texts.en:
Hausilagzam S. is 42 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger--a traditional nomadic housing tent--in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. His eldest, a son, is a student and the younger two children attend a local middle school while his wife manages a food retailing business at a local market called Ahdam. 

He started his transportation business in 2001 with working capital of 500,000 MNT and a Russian-brand small car. For nine successful years in business, Hausilagzam has been able to afford his elder son's tuition fees. He is a modest, hard-working, helpful businessman.  He says, “My only wish is to cover my children's education and have them become good people.” Hausilagzam is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to increase his working capital for their grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase more products

loans.name: Loyce

texts.en: Loyce K. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste, charcoal, rice and beans at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Loyce is 48 years old and is widowed.   She has 6 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to have a small farm for growing green vegetables for sale.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Prak

texts.en:
Prak C. is 39 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish around the busy market for more than nine years. She sells fish after buying them from her wholesale supplier and from other fishermen.

Prak C. is married to Banh Peuv, 39, who owns a motorcycle that he currently uses to provide a taxi service. This couple helps each other in order to generate money to support three of their kids who are students, while another one is no longer in school and is employed in a casino club.

Prak C.’s husband is concerned that his motor-taxi is getting old and often breaks down, so his income has been affected. To help remove this obstacle, Prak C. decided to request a loan from Kiva’s field partner, HKL, to be used to replace her husband’s old motor-taxi.

loans.use: To replace her husband's old motor-taxi

loans.name: Eang

texts.en: Eang S., 51, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. sells fruit for an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a plot of farmland to increase their agricultural produce. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a plot of farmland to increase agricultural produce

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity S. is currently in the business of selling groundnuts, fish and bags of maize at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more groundnuts and dried fish to sell.  Charity is 46 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 8 children and 4 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: Stock more groundnuts and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
This is Emily B., 42. She is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Rogelio B., a vendor and community marshal. They are blessed in their marriage with four children, one of whom is in high school while one is in elementary school. The two younger children are toddling around the house, bringing joy into the family. Emily and her husband are in good health and have strong physiques, which enables them to work hard for their future together.

Emily operates a ready-to-wear clothing store. She mainly offers children’s clothing, summer shorts (which are very popular in tropical Philippines), statement shirts and other basic everyday wear. These clothing items are made from sheer cotton fabrics, which are all suited to the hot and humid climate. Most customers only buy made-to-order clothes when it is really necessary, as it is more expensive. Emily’s customers are her immediate community members and neighbors. Emily earns a minimum of 250 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and designs of clothing to replenish and increase her current business inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Emily has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for years now and is regularly attending fellowship meetings*.

Emily dreams to be able to have her own house and lot someday through all her hard work on her business.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities and designs of clothing to replenish and increase her current business inventory

loans.name: Maguette

texts.fr:
Madame Maguette B. est une femme mariée de 39 ans. Elle habite dans le quartier de Ndeungagne  à Yoff. Elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 8 et 18 ans.
Madame B. a choisi l’activité de commerce par le biais de sa mère dans le but de réaliser des bénéfices. Ainsi elle s’active depuis plus de 20 ans dans la vente de poissons à la plage de Yoff. Auparavant elle exerçait  son activité au marché tilène. Elle est sociétaire de la caisse de Yoff depuis novembre 2003. Elle sollicite un crédit de 300 000 frs qui sera utilisé pour l’achat de poissons destinés a la vente. Son objectif est d’améliorer le cadre  de vie sociale de sa famille avec l’augmentation de ses revenus.
texts.en:
Ms. Maguette B. is a 39-year-old married woman.  She lives in the Ndeungagne district in Yoff.  She is a mother of eight children who are between 8 and 18 years old.  Maguette chose commerce through her mother with the goal of earning money.  Thus, she has been active for over twenty years in selling fish at the beach of Yoff.  In the past, she used to operate her business at the Tilène market. Maguette has been an associate of the Yoff branch since November 2003.  She is requesting a loan of 300,000 francs that will be used for buying fish to be sold.  Her goal is to improve her family's living conditions by increasing her revenues.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing her working capital

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem lives in a small city called Kasur. It is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is famous for its leather industry. She is living in the area of Basti Baraat Shah, where she moved 20 years ago.  

She is a 53-year-old who has given birth to two sons. She couldn’t educate her children due to financial constraints. Now both of them do work. Her eldest son has a bike-rental business and he also operates a grocery shop in the market. Her youngest son works in a factory on a monthly salary.
  
Naseem is married to A. R., who works in a vegetable market. He has a vegetable shop from where he sells seasonal vegetables to earn a profit.  

At the age of 53, Naseem is not in a position to work full-time to earn but she helps her son in his grocery shop business. She operates his shop in his absence but mainly she stays at home and does her household responsibilities.  

She has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her son in expanding his grocery store business. With the loan investment, he will buy grocery items to sell through his shop.  

Naseem is hopeful that her son will be able to increase his income by making positive use of the loan money. She is an Asasah regular loan user and is in her second loan cycle. In her previous loan year, she paid all the installments on time and built a good credit record. 

Note: In this photo, she is seated with her son, for whom she acquired a loan.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for a grocery shop

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
This is Jeanette S., a 41-year-old resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Precilo S., a mason. She is the mother of four children, one of whom is already working while the other three are still in school, one in college and the other two in high school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college - a dream for most Filipino parents like Jeanette as she herself was an elementary graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Jeanette operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from those round, palm-sized ones to the much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers come up with every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Besides rugs, Jeanette also retails bulk charcoal to her neighbors to be used as fuel for old-fashioned stoves. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She will also invest a portion of the loan to bulk buy sacks of charcoal to be repackaged and sold. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Jeanette dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She will also invest a portion of the loan to bulk buy sacks of charcoal to be repackaged and sold.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
This story is about N. Moses, a married man from Kajuzya group, Ibanda. Moses has been in the agricultural sector for more than 30 years. As for many Ugandan families, a mix of different agricultural activities has given his family an improved lease of life.
Moses has subsisted on a variety of agricultural products, and specialized in growing bananas and looking after cows. Although adverse weather conditions have affected his plantations constantly, Moses has managed to consolidate the gains he has made. As a result, his family of seven children has enjoyed the benefits and his children have all gone to good institutions of learning.
Moses makes a good monthly profit from sales of his agricultural products. He is very upbeat about this loan as he will be in a position to improve the mulching and gardening aspects of his farm and also increase his stock of animals. This will help him increase his amount of produce and sales revenue, providing him a base from which to achieve his objective of educating all his children.

loans.use: To purchase mulch and livestock

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
This is Remedios D., 58, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Victoriano D., a salesman, and she has five children, one of whom is already working while the younger children are at home and help Remedios manage the household and the business. By the grace of God, Remedios has managed to support her older child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Remedios, but as she herself has been a college undergraduate she believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.
Remedios operates a food business. She sells frozen cuts of cured, sweetened and spiced meats such as pork, sausages, hot dogs and ham. She peddles these rather like direct selling (but instead it is food rather than clothing and cosmetics). Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 250 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, Remedios is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy more cured meats. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Remedios dreams of being able to give her all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have a comfortable and well-off future with her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis.
