A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more cured meats

loans.name: Jean Damascene

texts.en:
Jean Damascene was born in 1981 and is married with one child who is 3 months of age.  Jean Damascene is a businessman but his wife is jobless; for that reason Jean Damascene works hard so that he provides all basic needs for his family. Jean Damascene is serious about his business; he starts his daily activities from 6 in the morning and works to 7 in the evening every day except on Sunday.

Jean Damascene is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing additional products such as beans, rice and so on. These new products in his shop will help him to attract more customers. With extra money which Jean Damascene expects to earn; he will save for his future.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
This is Gloria M., who is 45 and a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Florentino M., a contract painter. She is the mother of four children, two of whom are already working while the younger children are in college. By the grace of God, Gloria has managed to support her older children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all her children all the way through college -- a dream for most Filipino parents like Gloria as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Gloria operates a food business. She sells frozen cuts of cured, sweetened and spiced meats like pork, sausages, hot dogs and hams. She peddles these rather like direct selling, but instead it is food rather than clothing and cosmetics. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php9,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of cured meats. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Gloria dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have a comfortable and well-off future with her family. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship* co-members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of cured meats

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en:
Bushra is a 42-year-old widow and lives in the Pakistani city of Kasur, famous for its leather industry. She owns a small two-roomed house and has lived there with her family for over 21 years. She lost her husband a few years ago and this was a big loss in her life. Bushra is the mother of two sons and a daughter. Her elder son left his education after 8th grade and started helping Bushra in her business. Her younger son works in a motor workshop as a mechanic. Her only daughter also contributes to the family financially by doing embroidery work. 
Bushra is involved in the business of power looms (a machine that manufactures clothes and bed sheets). She manufactures bed sheets by taking orders from different factories and shops and supplying them with finished goods in the given time. She earns a valuable amount each time she sells a bed sheet.  
Bushra has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for the growth of her sheet-making business. She will invest her loan in her business and purchase thread in bulk. She is confident that she will be able to grow her business and income by investing money into it. She has run her business for the last 16 years and she knows that it has the potential to make good profits. Bushra is a regular loan user of Asasah and is on her second loan.

loans.use: To purchase thread in bulk to make bed sheets

loans.name: Reneline

texts.en:
This is Reneline G., 32, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Rodel, a pipe fitter, and is the mother of an active youngster. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. This is the dream of most Filipino parents like Reneline. As she herself has been a college undergraduate she believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents are able to leave to their children.
Reneline runs a direct-selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics, frozen cured meats and hams, detergent soap and other products through popular direct-selling brands such as Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, Pampanga’s Best (for the cured meats) and other direct-selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Reneline's regular customers are her neighbors and members of the local community. She earns a minimum of 5,800 PHP in sales every month.
To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Reneline dreams of being able to give her child a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Ndeye Marie

texts.fr:
Madame Ndeye Marie T. habite à Yoff Ndenatte. Elle  est mariée et mère de 3 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 6 et 21 ans.
Madame T. a embrassé l’activité de commerce pour gagner sa vie et satisfaire ses besoins. Ainsi depuis 15 ans elle s’adonne à la vente de glace. Parallèlement  elle pratique la vente de chaussures et d’habits depuis 2006. Ce qui l’intéressé le plus dans cette activité c’est son aspect lucratif. Elle est membre  de la caisse de Yoff depuis novembre 2006.Elle a déjà remboursé 2 prêts  antérieurs. Elle sollicite un troisième crédit  de 300 000 frs pour acheter des boubous d’été, des parfums et des chaussures en vue de renforcer son activité. Son rêvé  futur est de transformer leur maison familiale.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ndeye Marie T. lives in Yoff Ndenatte. She is married and the mother of three children whose ages vary from 6 to 21 years. Mrs. T. engaged in commercial activities to earn a living and satisfy her needs. So for the past fifteen years she has been selling ice. As a side business she has been selling shoes and clothing since 2006. What attracts her most in these activities is their profit-making aspect. She has been a member of the Yoff branch (of UIMCEC) since November 2006, and has already reimbursed two previous loans. She is requesting a third loan of 300,000 francs to buy summer “boubous” (dresses), perfume and shoes to strengthen her activity. In the future, she envisions transforming their family home.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: strenghten working capital

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara is a 21-year-old single woman who has worked as a hairdresser since 2006. Sara is a hard worker who is talented in her business and loves her business a lot. In addition to the hairdresser work, she also does faciA. treatment, makeup, tattoo, massage and waxing services, which increases her work and improves her picture among her clients. 

Sara seeks perfection in her work; she’s updated with every new product to use, in addition to new hairstyles and makeup. Sara believes that to deA. with people, you have to be patient and know how to deA. with different types of people. 

This is the first time Sara requests a loan from A. Majmoua and she’s hoping to increase her beauty products in addition to fixing certain important issues. Sara hopes to buy a sauna machine, a tanning machine and a laser machine so that her beauty center will be more than perfect.

loans.use: To increase her beauty products

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is a 27-year-old single woman who owns a computer and Internet shop. Khadija’s shop is visited by teenagers and adults in order to chat, play games and do certain university projects using the Internet. Her work improves during weekends, holidays and the summer season. She also sells CDs.

Her clients can be anyone but for the most part are her neighbors and villagers. She had financial challenges at the beginning, especially while starting her business. Khadija is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy new products, such as CDs and games, in addition to an important personal issue she has to solve.

loans.use: To buy new products

loans.name: Shahnaaz

texts.en:
Shahnaaz lives in Kasur, which is a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its leather industry. She lives in a small home that contains two rooms in the area of Qadirabad.
 
Shahnaaz is 44 years old and has given birth to three children. Both her son and elder daughter have left their education while her youngest daughter is studying in 5th standard. 

Her husband has a business of a power loom (a machine that manufactures clothes). He operates his business in a nearby market. Shahnaz supports her family by doing an embroidery and sewing business. She learned this art from her mother. She produces quality work and receives regular orders. They have three sewing machines at their home currently. Her elder daughter also helps her in her business and sometimes her friend also joins her in this business, taking guidance from Shahnaaz about sewing. 
 
She has applied for a loan from Asasah for the expansion of her embroidery business. With the help of the loan money, she will buy an embroidery machine which will be used by her daughter because presently, she makes handmade embroidery which delays completing the orders of the customers on time. She will also buy some embroidery material such as beads, colored thread and cloth to fulfill larger orders on time. 

She is hopeful that she will definitely earn better income after investing money in her business. She is regular loan user of Asasah and is in her fourth loan cycle. In previous loan years, she has proved herself a responsible client who never missed a single meeting.

loans.use: Purchase embroidery machine and embroidery material for embroidery business

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia lives in the small city of Kasur in Punjab province, Pakistan. Kasur is near to Lahore and famous for its leather industry. Safia is 58 years old and the mother of two sons. Both sons have left their education and started work. Both do different kinds of job to support the family financially. Safia's husband does manual labor, but at the old age of 60 it is very difficult for him to do such a tough job. However, in order to put three meals on the table he has no other option but to work.
Safia has an embroidery business. She is very good at her work and has more than 30 years' experience. Her work is very popular among her customers and she receives regular orders to make embroidered dresses.
Safia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her son who wants to buy kites for his kite-selling business. He supplies kites to customers in his local city as well as other cities, particularly Lahore. He has run this business for the last eight years and it brings a good profit. Flying kites is a popular sport in Pakistan, particularly at Basant festival. During this festival, people from all over the world come to Lahore to enjoy flying kites.
Safia is hopeful that by investing in her son’s business he will be able to make extra income each month as a result of improvements in his business. Safia is a regular loan user of Asasah and is on her fourth loan.

loans.use: To purchase kites for resale

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama A. is single and sells jollof rice (a popular West African dish) at Takoradi. She has been through senior high school.

Mariama is responsible for paying her utility bills and accommodation. Her loan will be used to buy a bag of rice to cook for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to build a shop for her business.

loans.use: To buy a bag of rice to cook for sale

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
This is Lydia D., 44, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Enrique D., a driver, and they are blessed with three children, two of whom are in college while the youngest is still in high school. By the grace of God, Lydia has managed to support her children’s schooling. At this time she is working hard to be able to send all her children all the way through college. It is one of her dreams in life because as she was a college undergraduate herself, she knows that a college diploma is the best inheritance she can bequeath to her children.
Lydia operates a ready-to-wear clothing store. She mainly offers children’s clothing, summer shorts (which are very popular in tropical Philippines), statement shirts, and other basic everyday wear. These clothes are made from sheer cotton fabrics, which are all suited to the hot and humid climate. Most customers only buy made-to-order clothes when it is really necessary, as it is more expensive. Elena’s customers are members of her immediate community and neighbors. She earns at least 200 PHP sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy a greater quantity of clothing, and more designs, to replenish and increase her current business inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Lydia dreams that her children will be able to finish their education. She knows it would be best for them. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy a greater quantity of clothes and more designs

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr:
Christine K.  est une femme de 34 ans, née à Gasabo, province de la Ville de Kigali capital du Rwanda. Elle est mariée et a un seul enfant qui a  3 ans. Christine et  sa famille habite à Kinyinya- Gasabo- Kigali, son niveau d’éducation est secondaire dans l’option de Biochimie. Elle est salariée dans une Eglise de PENTECOTE(ADEPR), Paroisse de Gasave ou elle est secrétaire de Révérend Pasteur de cette Eglise.
Le crédit contracté avec ACB est  le onzième, les précédents lui ont aidé d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et le présent prêt c’est pour amener l’eau dans sa maison. Ses épargnes lui permettent  de payer le loyer ou elle habite avec sa famille jusqu'à avoir sa maison laquelle elle veut installer les tuyaux d’eau.
Dans l’avenir, elle compte abandonner le secteur des salariés pour embrasser le commerce, bien sur, elle va commencer par un nouveau prêt et les épargnes antérieurs pour stabiliser sa capacité financière
texts.en:
Christine K. is 34 years old and was born in Gasabo, in the Province of the Town of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. She is married and has one three-year-old child. Christine and her hamily live in Kinyinya- Gasabo- Kigali. She attended school to the secondary level, choosing a Biochemistry option. She is employed by a Pentecostal Church (ADEPR) in the Parish of Gasave, where she is secretary to the Reverend Pastor of the Church. The loan granted by ACB is the 11th. The preceding loans enabled her to improve her family’s living conditions, and the present loan will serve to bring water into her home. Her savings are sufficient to pay the rent where she lives with her family until she can move to the house where she wants to install water pipes. In the future, she plans to stop being an employee and embark on commercial activities. This will of course require another loan, which along with previous savings will stabilise her financial capabilities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cost of installing water pipes.

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
This is Roselyn C., a 41-year-old resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Daniel C. Jr., an overseas Filipino worker. She is the mother of four children, one of whom is just starting elementary school while the younger children toddle around at home. By the grace of God, Roselyn managed to support her older child’s schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all her children all the way through college -- a dream for most Filipino parents like Roselyn as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Roselyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5-pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. Juanita earns by getting supplies at a  wholesale price and selling them at a piece rate. Roselyn’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Roselyn dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her own house and lot someday. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship co-members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Atta

texts.en:
Atta K. is married to a driver and has two children. She has received senior high school education.

Atta sells gari (cassava flakes) and secondhand clothes at Takoradi and uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of the home. She will use the loan to purchase more bags of gari to sell.

With the new profits from her expanded business, Atta plans to save to revive her secondhand clothes business.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of gari to sell

loans.name: Razia

texts.en:
Razia is 54 years old, married to M. S., and has no children. She lives in a three-roomed brick house in Kasur with her family. Kasur is a small city located near Lahore, Pakistan, and famous for its leather industry.
Her husband has run a grocery store in the market for the last five years. He sells daily use products such as cooking oil, lentils, spices and rice. His shop is located in a busy place in the market and he earns good profits from it every day.
Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband who wants to buy grocery items for his grocery shop. She hopes that by investing in the business her husband will be able to improve the business and increase his income. She is regular user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan. In previous years she has proved that she is a responsible client who always pays installments on time and never misses a single meeting.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for her husband's grocery shop

loans.name: Cheikh

texts.fr: Monsieur Cheikh D. est un jeune agriculteur-éleveur de 25 ans qui habite dans la localité de Wayembam  à  Bambilor. Il est marié mais n’a pas d’enfant. Après ses études primaires il s’est orienté vers l’agriculture avant de se spécialiser à l’élevage de poussins. Il a une expérience de plus de 10ans dans son activité. Il est membre de la caisse de Bambilor depuis janvier 2010. Il sollicite un crédit de 450000frs destiné  à l’élevage de 300 poussins. L’accroissement  de ses bénéfices  a travers ce financement lui permettra d’améliorer  sa situation sociale et plus précisément d’acquérir des mobiliers.
texts.en:
Mr. Cheikh D. is a 25-year-old poultry farmer living in the Wayembam district of Bambilor. He is married but has no children. After primary schooling he turned to vegetable farming before he specialised in raising chickens. He has over ten years’ experience in his business. He has been a member of the Bambilor branch (of UIMCEC) since January 2010. He is requesting a loan for 450,000 francs he will devote to raising 300 chicks. This loan will enable him to increase his earnings, improve his social situation and more specifically buy some furniture.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: strengthen working capital

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
This is Linda P., 53, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Hipolito P., a goldsmith, and mother of three children, all of whom are still in high school. By the grace of God, Linda has managed to pay for her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Linda, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Linda operates a jewelry business. Her husband makes the jewelry while she manages orders, finances and accounts. Gold jewelry, although not as common in the Philippines as silver jewelry, is still in demand, because of its higher value. In her business inventory are gold, silver and semi-precious and precious stones. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more supplies like silver. She also will invest a portion of the loan to pay the repair fee for the machine they use to solder the jewelry. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Linda dreams of being able to give her family a comfortable and well-off future. She also hopes that her family will soon know her personal Lord and Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy supplies like silver and pay for repair for a jewelry-making machine

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame N. sells Fante kenkey with fried fish at Takoradi (kenkey is fermented corn dough wrapped in corn or banana leaves; Fante kenkey is a variety of kenkey associated with the Fante people of Ghana). She has been selling Fante kenkey and fried fish for some time now and helps her husband to take care of her family.

Maame has received junior high education. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a palm wine tapper.

Maame’s loan will be used to order more Fante kenkey and fish to fry for sale. She plans on reinvesting the new profits generated as a result of her loan.

loans.use: To order more Fante kenkey to sell and fish to fry

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba A. sells provisions at Takoradi. She has no educational background. Her loan will be used to buy extra provisions to sell and she hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a piece of land.

Aba is married and takes care of seven dependents. Her husband is a farmer. She responsibly supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

loans.use: To buy extra provisions to sell

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena J., age 40, and her husband Arsenio have two children in high school and work hard to cover daily expenses and schooling costs.  For the past ten years, Elena has owned and run her own sari-sari store (general store) and vegetable stand.

Elena has requested a PHP 10,000 loan to purchase additional inventory for her store, including soft drinks and snacks.  The loan helps her buy in bulk so she can save money on transportation. She hopes additional inventory will help her attract more customers and eventually expand her business. 

Elena has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for several loan cycles and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes that earnings from her business will continue to provide for her children's schooling.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: additional inventory for her little store

loans.name: Revelieta

texts.en:
Revelieta D. L. C., age 30, and her husband, Eddie, have one child in elementary school and work hard to cover daily expenses.  Revelieta runs a small 'sari-sari' or general store that sells a number of goods including beverages, snacks, and toiletries.  Her business generates roughly PHP 7,000 per month. 

Revelieta has applied for a loan of PHP 9,000 to help her replenish her stock.  She would like to use the loan to purchase more toiletries and beverages, so that the added inventory might help her expand her business and generate more earnings each month.  

Revelieta has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since the beginning of 2010 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes that one day she will be able to purchase her own house and that her child will finish schooling.  

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: Replenish stock

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran lives with her family in Lahore which is famous for its history and culture. Lahore is the capital of Punjab province and the second largest city in Pakistan. Sughran lives in a four-room brick house with her family. She is 52 years old and has given birth to three daughters and three sons. Her three youngest children have got their education till 10th standard. The remaining three couldn’t get their education due to poor financial conditions in their family. So they started working at a young age and currently have their own businesses. Her two elder sons have a business selling spare parts and her elder daughter has opened a beauty salon at her home. 

Sughran does sewing from her house. She has contracts with different boutiques and stores selling women's ready-made garments. She finishes their orders on time and earns good profit on them. Her husband is a motor mechanic. He earns a reasonable income from his technical work. His workshop is located in the nearby market and it always remains busy because people trust him so much and come to him to repair their vehicles. 
 
Sughran has applied for a loan for the sixth time from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy the latest repair tools for his motor workshop and increase his income.  She is a very responsible member of Asasah and has always paid installments on time.

loans.use: Purchase latest repair tools for motor workshop

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina A. and her husband have four children.  Two are working, one is in high school, and one is in college.  Josefina works hard to cover her daily costs and to pay for her children's education.  Josefina runs a small business selling frozen meat to local people. 

Josefina has applied for a PHP 11,000 loan to help her restock her supply of frozen meats.  She believes that the additional inventory will allow her to slowly expand her business and generate more revenue.  Josefina has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2009 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  

She hopes that he partnership with CCT will allow her to become more successful.  She dreams of a bright future for her children.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: Restocking frozen meat

loans.name: Mena

texts.en:
Mena A. Sowah sells pampers, matches, pegs, steel wool and other items at Takoradi. Her loan will be used to buy more of her goods to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in her business.

Mena A. has received a senior high school level of education and is married with two children. Her husband is a driver.

loans.use: To buy more of her goods to sell

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
Charlotte was born in 1969 and is married with six children aged between 5 and 16. Charlotte takes care of two dependents. The first one is 19 years old and the younger one is 13.  Charlotte is a businesswoman; her husband also has a business. Charlotte owns a small business which sells various products such as: cosmetics, cooking oil, and so on. This is her fourth year of successful operation in business! The hours of her shop are from 7 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except on Sunday.

Charlotte is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing an additional products for her shop. This expansion will make her more efficient and effective and more successful.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou B. est une jeune mariée de 29 ans .Elle a choisi l’activité de commerce par amour. Elle est femme d’immigré. Et puisqu’elle dispose de beaucoup de temps libre elle a l’intention de débuter la vente de tissus et de parfums pour éviter d’être oisive. Son choix porte sur le placement de ses marchandises auprès  de ses voisins. Elle vient tout juste d’adhérer à la caisse de Dalifort ca fait 2 mois. Elle sollicite un crédit de 75 000 destiné à l’achat de marchandises. Les bénéfices réalisés lui permettront de prendre une partie de ses besoins en charge.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatou B. is a recently married woman, 29 years of age. She chose this business because she felt attracted to it. She is married to an immigrant. And because she has a lot of free time she would like to launch a business selling fabric and perfumes, in order to avoid being idle. Her choice of was determined by the type of merchandise she could sell in her neighborhood. It was only recently, two months ago, that she joined the Dalifort mutual fund. She is seeking a loan of 75,000 to purchase merchandise for sale. The anticipated revenue will allow her to cover part of her everyday needs.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Launching a business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Grace Anyango

texts.en:
Grace Anyango O. is 51 years old and comes from Siaya district. She is a widow and has three children who are school-going, aged 18, 20, and the last born four years old. 

Grace sells kerosene and has been in this business for three years. She is applying for a loan of Kshs 15,000 which she intends to use to buy several gallons of kerosene. This is her third loan that she is accessing from KADET LTD after successfully completing the previous ones.  She will use the profits made to cater for the family needs and pay school fees for her children.

She hopes to diversify into other businesses in the future.

loans.use: To buy gallons of kerosene to add to her stock

loans.name: Nazik

texts.en:
Nazik G.  was born in 1968 in Yerevan. She is married and has a son and a daughter. Her husband works in an ice-cream factory. At present, her son is in the army, protecting the Armenian state boarder. Her daughter is a student.

For about 10 years, Nazik has engaged in a  trading business. Nazik rents a stall in a trade center in Yerevan near her house, where she resells fruit and vegetables, which she buys from Malatia food market.  Nazik is a very lively person and she works very hard and thanks to that, she has a big quantity of customers, who are glad to do their shopping from Nazik's stall.

The profits from her sales allow her to take care of the needs of her family; supporting her son in the army; paying for her daughter's education. She is seeking a loan of 150,000 AMD to add her fruit and vegetable assortment.

loans.use: To add to her  fruit and vegetable assortment

loans.name: Eugenie

texts.en:
Eugenie was born in 1962 and is married with 8 children, aged between 6 and 12. Eugenie owns a small business selling various clothes. This business is profitable and that is the reason why it was chosen by her so that she can solve her family problems. Eugenie’s business is well organized and known. She employs one person from her community as a helper. Eugenie has an experience of 10 years in her business; even though she is seasoned in her business, she does not  make enough money from it.

Eugenie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business which will allow her to attract more customers. She will be able to create new jobs as well. Having more customers will help her to earn more profits which are her main target. As a part of business, Eugenie studies English which is the language used in business and socializes with her children as well.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Blaise Theoneste

texts.en:
Blaise Theoneste was born in 1983 and is single. Blaise lives with his parents where he has to participate in supporting his family. Blaise has been a businessman since 2008.  He owns a business selling clothes.  Blaise has chosen this business obviously because is profitable in the city where his business is located. Blaise’s shop is open from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day.

Blaise Theoneste is now requesting a Kiva loan Via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business which will allow him to satisfy his customers and earn more profits as well. With any extra money Blaise Theoneste expects to save and to change his standard of living.

loans.use: Expanding isr business

loans.name: Juntas Podemos Group

texts.es:
Descripción:	El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Juntas Podemos, se conformó en fecha 27 de Julio del 2.010, con mucho esfuerzo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
Además del trabajo independiente de cada una, también desarrollan actividades en forma conjunta  para recaudar fondos con el fin de contar con un capital dentro del grupo, y  de apoyar económicamente  a sus familias en especial.
Una de las integrantes  es la de la Sr. Ramona B.  quien se dedica a venta de carbón, nos comenta que mediante el  crédito  pudo mejorar bastante su actividad y su nivel de vida e ingreso económico. 
Ella nos comenta que mediante este negocio  ayuda a  la economía de la  familia ya con el mismo  mejoró bastante, y actualmente posee  además del ingreso de su marido quien trabaja como jornalero, con  el ingreso de la venta de carbón.
 Según la Sra. Ramona   mencionó que las actividades que realizan con la Fundación Paraguaya es muy importante ya que mediante ella pudieron  desarrollar sus  capacidades de trabajo.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de carbón ya que hay mucha demanda por la temporada fría.
texts.en:
Description: The Juntas Podemos (Together We Can) committee was founded on July 27, 2010 with much effort but united and mutually supportive within the program. Besides each member’s individual work they also develop group activities to earn funds so that the group can have capital and be able to support their families economically. One of the group members is Mrs. Ramona B. who is a charcoal merchant. She commented to us that the loan allowed her to improve her business quite a bit as well as her standard of living and income. She also comments that the family’s economy improved considerably with the loan. She can now add her income from the charcoal sales to her husband’s salary as a day laborer. According to Ramona, activities they undertook with Fundación Paraguaya were very important because they developed their work skills. She is asking for funds to buy charcoal because demand is very high during the cold season.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal.

loans.name: Yeimy Yhonatan

texts.es:
El señor es casado, tiene dos hijos menores, vive en el barrio Conavi de esta ciudad, posee una microempresa de producciones, donde comercializa espacios publicitarios, tiene casa propia y su pareja posee una cantina en una escuela muy conocida de la ciudad.
 Son una familia es muy trabajadora y con ganas de superarce cada dia y con miras en agrandar cada vez mas su actividad actual, agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya por los buenos servicios que le ha brindado como asi tambien el queda comprometida en cumplir en tiempo y forma el compromiso adquirido con la empresa para así en un determinado tiempo poder contar nuevamente con el apoyo de la Institucion para cualquier emprendimiento dentro de su empresa.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de equipos informáticos para la empresa.
texts.en:
The gentleman is married and has two minor children. He lives in this city’s Conavi neighborhood and has a small production company where he sells ad space. He owns his own home and his wife has a snack bar in one of the city’s well known schools. They are a very hard working family who wants to improve daily in order to grow each time in their current work. He is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the good services rendered and he pledges to repay in a timely fashion so that he might be eligible for future assistance if needed. He is asking for funds to buy computer equipment for the firm.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy computer equipment for the firm.

loans.name: Ntirandekura

texts.en:
J. was born in 1978 and is single. J. lives with his parents and that means that he has to participate in supporting his family, providing for all the needs in his family. J. has been a businessman since 2004. J. owns a business selling phones in Kigali city. This business is profitable and organized but he is not able to satisfy his customers' needs.

J. is now requesting a Kiva loan for the purpose of expanding his business so that he can satisfy his customers which can help him to attract more of them. With this loan, J. will be able to sort out his problems through the profits.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Esperence

texts.en:
Esperence was born 1968 and is divorced with five children, aged between 5 and 15. Esperence has been a businesswoman since last year meaning that she has an experience of 12 months in her business. In the family of Esperence, there is one person who works in the public sector.

Esperence owns a business selling breads and cakes in her place of residence. She employs six people from her community as helpers and her business is open from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day except on Sunday.

Esperence is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business which will help her to attract more customers and earn more profits to be used in her family and in her business as well.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Marguerithe

texts.en:
Marguerithe was born in 1960 and has six children who are between 6 and 27 years old. Her husband is a farmer and some of their children are in school. Together with her husband she has managed to pay their children’s school fees.

She sells sorghum and beans.  She hopes to purchase beans and sorghum on a larger scale in order to make more profits.

loans.use: Buying beans and sorghum for resale

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en:
Seraphine was born in 1977 and has two children who are 9 and 5 years old; both are in school. Her husband works together with her.

Seraphine has a shop selling various household items and soft drinks.  She has been in this business for four years and she is requesting a loan in order to buy more household items such as salt, sugar, boxes of matches, etc. 

Seraphine hopes to increase her capital as well by buying more items with the profits and building her savings. In the future she plans to have a wholesale shop with a variety of household items.  She also hopes to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: Buying household items for resale

loans.name: Dani

texts.en:
Dani was born in 1964 and has seven children who are between 8 months and 20 years old. All his children are in school and, together with his wife, he has been able to afford to pay for their medical insurance. His wife is a farmer; he assists her at times.
 
Dani sells cattle and has done this business for 16 years. He is requesting a loan in order to buy more cattle. With the profits, he plans to pay his children’s school fees, buy food for his family and save a small amount. He also hopes to invest in his business to increase his income.

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Bosco

texts.en:
Bosco is married with six children. His youngest child is 6 years old while his eldest is 16 years old. They are all in school. Bosco’s wife is a farmer, however she also helps her husband with his business. 

Bosco sells cattle and has done this business for eight years.  With the loan, he hopes to buy more cattle to sell, and with the profits he wishes to renovate his house and build up his savings.

loans.use: Buying more cattle

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes was born in 1960. She is married to a farmer and they have seven children. She is very hardworking and she has helped her husband pay her children’s school fees.

She sells sorghum beer and green bananas on a retail basis. She also sells sorghum grain, both retail and wholesale. She has done this business for 25 years. The black plastic container by her side contains sorghum beer. She is requesting a loan in order to increase her capital by buying more sorghum and green bananas. Agnes hopes to pay her children’s school fees and have some savings with the profits.

loans.use: Buying sorghum and green bananas for sale.

loans.name: Olivier

texts.en:
Olivier is 24 years old and he is still single.  Olivier owns a shop where he sells a variety of goods and this is his 3rd year in this business.  His shop is open from 6 am to 9 pm every day.

Although Olivier has owned a shop for about 3 years, his capital is still too low to expand meaningfully.  To remedy this, he needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  With this loan, Olivier will expand his shop through adding a large quantity of foodstuffs mainly Irish potatoes, beans, rice, cooking oil, etc.  If successful, Olivier will hopefully increase his sales as well as profits which in turn will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business for a better financial stability.

loans.use: a variety of goods including foodstuffs

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en:
Jeannette was born in 1972 and is married with four children aged 4 to 13. Jeannette’s husband is an evangelist. Jeannette owns a business selling maize flour; her business is well-known and organized as well. This business is profitable and that is the reason why it was chosen by her. Jeannette has an experience of 8 years and employs two people  from her community as helpers so that her business runs well. Jeannette's shop is open from 6 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day except on Saturday. 

Jeannette is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing rice as an additional product in her shop. Once this business is done, Jeannette will be able to attract more customers which is the best way of earning more profit.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Emerence

texts.en:
Emerence is 26 years old, married with one child of three months, and she takes care of two dependents.  Emerence makes a living by selling a variety of goods in her shop and this is her 2nd year in this business.  The business hours are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Emerence needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  Once given this loan, she hopes to invest in the purchase of foodstuffs mainly beans, rice, peas, Irish potatoes, etc.  With this additional business, Emerence will hopefully earn more profit which in turn will allow her to increase her capital.  Once her capital is increased, she will keep reinvesting in her business for a better financial stability in the future.

loans.use: a variety of foodstuffs

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda H. is a widow who lives in Prk. Bukang Liwayway, Brgy. Tanglaw, Puerto Princesa, Palawan. She earns her living by operating four business ventures: building rental, pension houses, tricycle operator and a general store. Erlinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Erlinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 23,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,800, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 15th loan cycle, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to pay for building maintenance that will be very helpful in her business and to continue to save up for future house renovation. Erlinda H. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Building maintenance

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
El señor Francisco es soltero, vive en un departamento en alquiler en la zona Miraflores de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor Francisco trabaja en la Caja Nacional del Seguro y con el sueldo que gana mantiene su hogar.
El crédito solicitado es para su formación educativa para continuar sus estudios profesionales.
Esta es la segunda ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Francisco is single and lives in a rented apartment in the Miraflores area of La Paz. Francisco works in the Caja Nacional del Seguro (National Security Bank) and uses his salary to maintain his home. He is requesting a loan for his education to continue his professional studies. This is the second time that he has requested a loan and our socioeconomic analysis qualifies him favorably for access to credit.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To continue with his professional studies

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianey

texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianey is 27 years old and he is married with two children, 2 and 5 years old.  Jean Marie Vianey owns a shop where he sells a variety of goods and this his 3rd successful year in this business.  The business hours are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Jean Marie Vianey needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, he will start selling foodstuffs as they are highly demanded by a large number of his customers.  With this sale of foodstuffs, he hopes that his profits will increase.  Once these profits increase, one portion will be used in taking care of his family and another portion will be used in further reinvestment for a better financial stability.

loans.use: a variety of foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Artashes

texts.en: Artashes A. has been managing a clothing business for a few years. In the past, he was purchasing the clothing from a neighboring country. Later on, Artashed decided to foster the local economy by opening a local clothing production facility. With the loan, he is planning to purchase fabric for clothing production.

loans.use: Purchasing fabric for clothing production

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 30 years and she is married with two children who are 2 and 4 years old.  Vestine is commonly known in the business of selling foodstuffs and she has been in this business for a long time.  Her business hours are from 6 am to 9 pm every day.

Vestine needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Vestine will increase her business through purchasing a large quantity of foodstuffs including wheat.  If successful, Vestine will keep expanding her business till she becomes a wholesaler.  If so, she really hopes that her business will be financially stable.

loans.use: a large quantity of foods for sale

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen M. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Masikap, Brgy. 1, Roxas, Palawan. She earns her living by being a dried fish dealer. Her husband Hernie M., who is 44 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who range from 16 to 18 years old. Helen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Helen has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,400, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 14,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she could continue to save up for the future of her family and for her children's education. Helen M. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Gilla

texts.en: Gilla B. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Rizal, Brgy. Poblacion, Dalaguete, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store business. Her husband Ignacio B., who is 50 years old, works as a maintenance man to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 22 and 23 years old. Gilla joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gilla has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 18,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000, which she intends to use as additional capital so that she could continue to save up for the future of her children and to buy more goods for her general store. Gilla B. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en: Ester F. is a 53-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general-store business. She lives in Brgy. Pugalo, Alcoy, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general-store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Ester is now borrowing PHP 10,500 so that she could buy additional stock to sell in her general store. This will be her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ester aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of more stock to sell

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en:
Priscilla is a married woman with one child who attends school. She has been operating her business of selling second-hand clothes for the last year. With the 30,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to open a clothes-selling stall and purchase a bale of clothes. She has no other source of income. Priscilla sells at the market and door-to-door to her neighbors and passersby.

The major challenge she experiences is high transport costs. Priscilla hopes to have a boutique in the future. She decided to work with Yehu to get financial assistance to boost her business. She lives at a rental house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To open a clothes-selling stall and purchase a bale of clothes

loans.name: Mujeres Activas Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formó gracias a las Señora Carmen Ramona V. Gimenez que vive en la cuidad de Villarrica. Encantadas aceptaron conformar el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras nombrándolo Comité •• Mujeres Activas••.


 Ellas se dedican a la Artesanía elaborando prendas de vestir, manteles, camisas, etc. y muchas otras creaciones que son heredadas de sus madres, abuelas, pasando estos conocimientos de generación en generación. 


También muchas de las integrantes trabajan en pequeños comercios para la cual le fue de mucha  importancia la ayuda que les ofreció Fundación Paraguaya.


Cabe destacar que mediante el comité ellas lograron aumentar  sus ganancias
Y poder cada día mejorar aun más sus condiciones de vida.

Una de las integrantes es la señora Carmen quien se dedica a la fabricación y venta de artesanía en ao po´i (es una tela especial de hilos de algodón que son utilizados para fabricar las prendas de artesania), ella fabrica camisas, vestidos, manteles y otros y son muy admirados por la gente lo que hace que la venta sea muy rápido.
La señora Carmen es muy trabajadora y comenta que seguirá trabajando ya muy satisfactorio para ella ayudar a su familia.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de tela ao po´i.
Es importante mencionar que algunas de las señoras fabrican prendas que se exportan en muchos países.
texts.en:
This committee was formed thanks to Mrs. Carmen Ramona V. Gimenez, who lives in the city of Villarrica. They enthusiastically agreed to form a Women Entrepreneurs Committee, naming it the "Mujeres Activas" ('Active Women') committee." They work in handcrafts, making clothing, tablecloths, shirts, etc. and many other creations inherited from their mothers and grandmothers, who passed this knowledge from generation to generation. Many of the members also work in small businesses, so the help offered them by Fundación Paraguaya was very important to them. It is worth pointing out that through the committee they were able to increase their earnings and improve their living conditions even more everyday. One of the members is Carmen, who makes and sells ao po´i handicrafts (ao po´i is a special cotton fabric used for making handcrafted items). She makes shirts, dresses, tablecloths and other items, and they are much admired by other people, which makes them sell quickly. Carmen is very hardworking and says that she will continue working and is very happy to be able to help her family. She is asking for the loan to buy ao po´i cloth. It is important to mention that some of the women make items that are exported to many countries.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ao po´i fabric

loans.name: Maria Alicia

texts.es: Maria Alicia de 49 años, Comenzó hace años con el negocio de nintendo, mas tarde cuando los aparatos se dañaron, decide empezar a vender verduras y carne de pollo el cual lo destazaba y lo vendía a un precio mas cómodo poco a poco con esfuerzo realizo establecer su pulpería. En su negocio asisten diferentes personas sus vecinos, amigos y familiares. La ubicación de su negocio es en su vivienda trabaja sola desde muy temprano hasta las 10 de la noche todos los días. Ella quiere comprar con el préstamo golosinas, detergentes, pan, jugos y desinfectantes para tener más ingresos. En el futuro quiere surtir más su negocio y terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
María Alicia, 49, started a few years ago with a Nintendo business. However, when the equipment was damaged she began to sell vegetables and chicken that she’d butcher and sell for a fair price. Gradually, she set up a grocery store. Various neighbors, friends and relatives are her customers. Her store is located in her home and she tends to it by herself from very early until 10pm every day. She wants to use the loan to buy sweets, detergent, bread, juices and disinfectants to increase income. In the future she’d like to stock the store even more and finish building her house.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en:
Jean Baptiste is 38 years old, married with 3 children.  Jean Baptiste is a hard-working businessman selling shoes.  He has been in this business for a long time and the business hours are from 8 am to 6 pm every day.

Jean Baptiste needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, he will purchase different styles of shoes for sale.  With these additional shoes to sell, he will hopefully increase his sales as well as profits.  With these profits, he will keep reinvesting in his business for a better financial stability and in addition to that, the living conditions of his family will improve.

loans.use: Different styles of shoes for sale

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en: Luciana E. is a widow who lives in Pantalan, Brgy. Asia, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, the buying and selling of rice, and farming. Luciana joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Luciana has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 23,000, which she intends to use to purchase a rice field so that she could continue to save up for future acquisition of rice fields in order to earn more income and improve their living conditions. Luciana E. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase a rice field

loans.name: Ma. Jovelyn

texts.en: Ma. Jovelyn E. is a 36-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: food vending and farming. She lives in Prk. Maantud, Brgy. Dumalan, Dalaguete, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food vending and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP). Ma. Jovelyn is now borrowing PHP 10,000 for additional capital. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ma. Jovelyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for business

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is a married woman with one child who is too young for school. Her husband is a driver by profession. Martha has been operating her hair dressing business for the last two years, going door to door to her neighbors and passersby. With the 20,000 KES loan. she wants to open a hair dressing shop and  and purchase hair supplies. She faces the major challenge of high transport cost incurred when moving from door to door. 

She hopes that she will start and own a big hair dressing shop in the future. Her aim of working with Yehu is to get the financial assistance she needs to improve her business.

loans.use: To open a hair dressing salon

loans.name: Ma. Magdalina

texts.en:
Ma. Magdalina D. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Maantud, Brgy, Dumalan, Dalaguete, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  a videoke bar and a general store. Her husband Pedro D., who is 39 years old, works as a miner and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 11 children who are 8 months to 20 years old.  

Ma. Magdalina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Magdalina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing PHP 14,000 which she intends to use to expand her business so that she can continue to save up for their future and provide a better life for her children. Ma. Magdalina D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Amri

texts.en:
Amri is a widow with four children, all of whom attend school. She has been selling firewood for the last three years. She sells retail to her neighbors, most of whom are women.

In addition, she has houses that she rents as an additional source of income. Previously she operated a business selling flat breads. With the loan of 20,000  KES, she wants to purchase a bundle of firewood to sell as wholesale. 

Amri faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes that in future she will be able to sell charcoal in wholesale. She decided to work with Yehu so she could get financial assistance. The mission of Yehu is to improve small-scale entrepreneurs by providing sustainable financial services. She owns a house with no electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of firewood.

loans.name: Afissa

texts.en:
Afissa is 55 years old and she is a widow.  Afissa makes a living by selling different kinds of fruit and this is her 10th successful year in this business.  Her business hours are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

 After realizing that she is not satisfying the demand of her customers,  Afissa thinks she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, she will expand her business through purchasing more fruit for sale.  If successful, Afissa will start saving and keep investing in her business for a better financial stability in the future.

loans.use: a large quantity of fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Nabikakala Women's Club Group

texts.en:
N. Dimintiria is a member of Nabikakala Women's Club of Mubende, just like the others in the group photo. 

Hard work and a vivacious personality has helped N. Dimintiria create a thriving business selling alcohol in Kyamukona, Mubende. This married mother of four children has been running this business for seven years. She earns about 200,000 Ugandan shillings. 

Her current challenge is the lack of capital to purchase more inventory such as beer and soft drinks. This loan will help her expand the business so she can earn more revenue to meet her family's needs and educate her children.

loans.use: Restocking beer and soft drinks

loans.name: Carmen Mercedes

texts.es:
Carmen de 35 años, ella tiene una papelería pequeña en la parte delantera de su casa, vive en una zona periurbana de Guayaquil llamada “Fortín” y caracterizada por su pobreza y sus caminos de tierra. 

Inicio el negocio desde que la abandono su esposo para poder mantener a sus tres hijos de 8, 6 y 2 años. Con sus ahorros compro papelería y readecuo la parte delantera de su casa. Ahora ella trabaja desde las 07h00am hasta las 00h00pm todos los días. Una de las dificultades que tienes es dejar solo a sus hijos cuando ella va a ser las comprar de la papelería.   

Con el préstamo quiere comprar papelería, cuadernos, laminas para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener mas grande y surtido su negocio.
texts.en:
Carmen, 35, has a small stationery shop in the front part of her house. She lives in a periurban section of Guayaquil called “Fortín” that is notable for its poverty and unpaved roads. She started the business after she was abandoned by her husband and she was left having to support her three children who are 8, 6 and 2 years of age. She used her savings to buy paper goods and she refurbished the front of her house. Now, she is open from 7am until midnight every day. One of the difficulties she faces is having to leave her children unattended when she goes out to buy her stock. She wants to use the loan to buy stationery items like: notebooks and notebook paper. In the future she’d like her business to be even larger and better stocked.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For notebook paper and notebooks.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 35 years old, married with 5 children who are 3, 8, 10, 13 and 15 years old.  Christine owns a shop where she sells foodstuffs.  She has been in this business for one year and the hours of her business are from 6 am to 9 pm every day.

Although Christine has been in this business for one year, her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully.  Thus she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  Once given this loan, Christine hopes that she will expand her business through purchasing more foodstuffs for sale which in turn will allow her to satisfy her customers and increase her profits.  With these profits, she will improve the living conditions of her family and start saving for the future.

loans.use: a variety of foodstuffs

loans.name: Kasongodde Women's, Mubende Group

texts.en:
Operating a retail shop that sells general merchandise is a formidable business venture from which John K. (age 48) manages to earn some money to fulfill his life and meet his family's necessities. His shop is in Kasongodde trading centre, Mubende. 

It is difficult to begin from scratch and build a strong businesses. John's need to support his six children has made him settle for his current business. Because he had very little capital from his previous farming business to start up his retail shop business, he is seeking a loan. He wants to expand his business into a bigger enterprise and to purchase enough stock so that he has sufficient supplies for his customers. He earns about 50,000 a week from his shop

John wants to build a family house when he gets more profits.

loans.use: Purchase more stock for his store

loans.name: Chomimabaj Group

texts.es: Don Oscar Rene C. E. es casado, tiene 5 hijos, es una persona analfabeta, el se dedica al comercio (compra y venta de Cinchos)  tiene 18 años ya con este negocio. Contando con entusiasmo y la ayuda de algunos vecinos organizan un grupo, para poder solicitar un préstamo. El Grupo solidario se  denomina Chonimabaj,  el nombré indica la ubicación de cada uno de ellos. El grupo cuenta con cuatro integrantes 3 hombres y una mujer, quienes se dedican a diversas actividades entre ellos podemos mencionar, la crianza de animales,  y venta de Cacahuates, y ropa americana.   El préstamo el lo utilizará para compra de mercadería y así incrementar el volumen de ventas, para segir adelante con la ayuda de sus hijos y espera que su negocio sea más grande y productivo.
texts.en:
Mr. Oscar René C. E. is married and has five children. He is illiterate and has been a belt merchant for 18 years. With lots of enthusiasm and support from some neighbors they organized a group to request a loan. The group is called Chonimabaj, which is an anagram made up of each of their locations. The group has three men and one woman who are in a variety of activities among which are: animal raising, peanut sales and American clothes sales. He will use the loan to buy merchandise to increase sales volume in order to continue forward with his children’s help. He hopes his business will grow and be productive.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy belts.

loans.name: Mwanandi

texts.en:
Mwanandi A. is a married woman with five grown children. She lives in her own house without electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. She has been making money by weaving mats for the last five years. She sells them from her home to her neighbors and passersby, but she faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business.

Mwanandi’s major goal working with Yehu is to get financial assistance to boost her business. With 10,000 KES she wants to open a retail shop and buy more weaving materials. She hopes to sell the mats wholesale in the future.

loans.use: To open a retail shop and buy more weaving materials

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie A. is a married woman with two children who are 17 and 19 years old. Her husband, Benjamin A., is a 49-year-old businessman. They live in Purok Taloot in Barangay Poblacion, located within Sibonga municipality on Cebu Island. Rosemarie earns her living operating an internet cafe and raising pigs.

Rosemarie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past three loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosemarie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 10,000 PHP, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.

For this, her fourth loan, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase a new computer for her internet café. With the profits she can repair and maintain her equipment and continue to save up for their future. Rosemarie A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase a new computer

loans.name: Vy´a Renda Group

texts.es:
Este comité se formó gracias al deseo de las señoras de formar un grupo para trabajar en forma conjunta y al mismo tiempo tratar de mejorar las actividades que cada una realiza para ayudar a su familia.

 Así como muchas mujeres de Villarrica las mayoría de las señoras de este comité se dedican a la Artesanía realizando bordados en tela ao po´i confeccionando numerosos artículos que más tarde llevan a la venta. 
Estos trabajos lo realizan en forma paralela a  otras actividades cotidianas en sus hogares.
La señora Emilce quien es presidenta del comité es una señora muy trabajadora que también trabaja con artesanías de ao po´i.
Ella fabrica prendas de vestir para hombre y para damas y los vende a muchos negocios de Villarrica y también recibe pedidos de negocios de Asunción.
Solicita el crédito para la compra de telas de ao po’i.
texts.en:
This committee was formed thanks to the desire of the women to form a group to work together and at the same time try to improve the activities each performs to help her family. Like many of the women of Villarica, most of the members of this committee are craftswomen making ao po’i (typical Paraguayan embroidery); they make numerous articles for subsequent sale. These activities are performed alongside their daily household chores. Emilce is the committee president; she is a very hard working woman who also makes ao po’i crafts. She makes clothing items for both men and women that she sells to many stores in Villarica. She also gets orders from stores in Asunción. She is requesting funds to buy ao po’i fabrics.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ao po´i (Paraguayan embroidery) fabrics.

loans.name: Maredin

texts.en:
