Maredin G. is a married woman with six children who are 20 to 29 years old. Her husband, Rolando, who is 52 years old, works as a barangay captain and helps in his wife's business activities. They live in Purok 1, a part of Barangay Caningay in Candoni municipality, Negros Occidental province. Maredin buys and sells charcoal and operates a general store.

Maredin joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Maredin has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 17,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 15,000 PHP, thus lifting the family's standard of living.

For this, her 16th loan, she is borrowing 20,500 PHP, which she intends to use to hire more laborers to work their rice field and to buy more stock for her general store. With the profits she would like to make some home repairs and continue to save for the education of her children. Maredin G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her store & hire laborers

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is married. His wife is a business woman. They have three children - two attend school, while the third is one and a half years old and still too young for school. They live in a rental house with no electricity or piped water. Their greatest monthly expense is paraffin oil.

Julius has been operating his carpentry business for the last six years. He sells his goods on a retail basis to his neighbors and passersby. With the 20,000 Kshs he is requesting, he wants to purchase a lorry of timber. His major challenge is the lack of capital to purchase more stock. He hopes that someday he will open a showroom to market his products. Julius decided to work with Yehu to gain access to financial services to improve his business.

He also earns income from his wife’s business earnings.

loans.use: To purchase a lorry of timber.

loans.name: Nicha

texts.fr:
Jeune femme de 24 ans, mariée et mère d’un enfant. En 2007 elle se lance dans la vente des produits cosmétiques, mèches, et tissages. Son étalage est juste devant sa maison, donc tous les matins, elle étale sa marchandise et le soir elle la fait rentrer.
Ses ventes journalières sont de 15000 à 20000 fers par jour, ses clientes sont les femmes du quartier, les clientes des salons de coiffure qui sont aux alentours.

A l’octroi de son prêt elle a l’intention d’acheter des produits de beauté comme des douzaines de  lait de toilette, des crèmes de beauté, savons de toute marques , des mèches et tissages de toutes qualités …
Elle épargne parce qu’a l’avenir elle veut aller dans une école professionnelle de coiffure et  a la fin de sa formation ouvrir son propre salon de coiffure ou elle pourrait employer au moins deux coiffeuses.
texts.en:
This young 24-year-old woman is married and has one child. In 2007, she started selling cosmetic products, hair extensions and weaves. She displays her merchandise right outside her home, bringing it out every morning and putting it away every night. Her daily sales average 15,000 to 20,000 francs. Her customers are women from the neighborhood, clients of the local hair salons. With her loan, she plans to purchase beauty products including dozens of lotions, face creams, various brands of soaps, hair extensions and weaves of any grade. She is saving in order to enroll in a professional hairstyling school. Upon finishing her training, she would like open her own hair salon and hire at least two hairdressers.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase hair extensions, weaves, cosmetic products and imported beverages

loans.name: Nancy Nereysy

texts.es:
Nancy de 28 años, vive en una zona periurbana de Guayaquil llamada “Fortín” y caracterizada por su pobreza y sus caminos de tierra. Tiene una pollea en el patio de su casa. 

Por la falta de oportunidades hace 6 años retiro el fondo de reserva que tenia y lo invirtió en pollos, creció muy rápido su negocio por la buena acogida que le dieron sus vecinos, ahora ella tiene un criadero de pollos y trabaja desde las 06h00. Vende los pollos a sus vecinos y a las tienda de por su sector ya muertos y pelados. 

Para tener una mejor presentación de sus pollos ella quiere readecuar la pollera, por eso con el préstamo quiere comprar bloques y pollos. En el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa porque ahora es de caña y que a uno de sus hijos le den una beca para que pueda estudiar.
texts.en:
Nancy is 28 years old, lives in a semi-urban neighborhood of Guayaquil called "Fortin" and is characterized by her poverty and her dirt roads. She has a chicken coop on the patio of her house. Due to a lack of opportunities, six years ago she withdrew the savings she had and invested in chickens. Her business grew very rapidly because of the good reception her business got from her neighbors. Now she has the chicken coop and works beginning at six in the morning. She sells the chickens (dead and skinned) to her neighbors and to the stores in her neighborhood. To better present her chickens, she wants to rebuild the coop; for this reason, with the loan she wants to purchase both blocks and chickens. In the future, she wants to finish building her house because right now it is constructed from cane and also give one of her sons a scholarship so that he can study.

Translated from Spanish by Tess Siemer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Chickens and Blocks

loans.name: Leandre  Martin

texts.fr:
Homme de 49ans, marié et père de 4 enfants dont l'âge varie de 27ans à 3ans. Trois de ses enfants sont scolarisé.
Après avoir reçu sa première bourse universitaire, ayant une charge de 3 personnes   il se lança dans le commerce d’alimentation en 1988 avec un capital de 300000 Frs et sa vente moyenne journalière est de 60000 frs.

Avec ce prêt il veut  renforcer son stock en achetant 2 casiers de boissons non alcoolisée, 2 cartons de boîte de conserve, 1 carton de jus de fruits, 4 packs d’eau mayo et autres produits. 

Il a des grandes ambitions ouvrir a la longue plusieurs alimentations ou les désirs de ses clients seront satisfaits. 

Très aimable, tout le monde le connait, il fait preuve d'une bonne moralité et est entrain de se battre pour la prospérité de ses enfants dans des bonnes écoles et construire une maison pour sa famille.
texts.en:
This 49-year old man is married and father to four children, whose ages range from three to 27 years old. Three of his children are at school. Having received his first university grant and with the responsibility for three people, he set himself up in the food business in 1988 with a capital of 300,000 francs. His average daily turnover is 60,000 francs. With this loan he wants to boost his stock by buying two crates of non-alcoholic drinks, two cartons of canned foods, one carton of fruit juice, four packs of water, mayonnaise and other products. In the long term he has a big ambition to open several food shops where his customers wishes will be satisfied. He is a very pleasant person, whom everyone knows. He has proved to be of good character and is fighting for his children to be able to prosper in good schools and to be able to build a house for his family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of three cartons of canned foods, non-alcoholic drinks, two cartons of tinned milk

loans.name: Aissatou

texts.fr:
Madame Aissatou Traoré est une veuve de 39 ans qui habite dans la localité de Dalifort. 
Madame Traoré a l’amour du commerce et dispose d’un emplacement au sein de la maison familiale qu’elle souhaite aménager pour débuter le commerce de produits cosmétiques. Elle est sociétaire  de la caisse de Dalifort  depuis 6 ans. Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs pour acheter des produits et  mettre en place son stock. Selon madame Traoré l’impact social que pourrait avoir ce financement serait de régler ses besoins personnels et aussi d’assister ses proches avec la réalisation de bénéfices.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aissatou Traoré is a 39-year-old widow living in the town of Dalifort. Mrs. Traoré loves commerce and has an area at her disposal in the family home where she wishes to start selling cosmetic products. She has been a member of the Dalifort credit union for six years. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 francs to buy merchandise and set up a display. Mrs. Traoré believes in the social impact of making profits to fulfill her personal needs and to help her family.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To start a commercial activity

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida I. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Catarman I, Cordova, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 5 business ventures: a Sari-Sari (General) Store, Ready to Wear (RTW), Electronic Re-loading, Water Vending and another retailing business. Her husband, Arnel I., who is 39 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living. They have 2 children who are 16 and 20 years old.

Leonida joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Leonida has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 14,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 23,000 which she intends to use for additional funds for her business. Her goals are to continue to save for the future, let her children finish their studies and to expand the businesses.

Leonida I. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. (Dungganon is a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable.) Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional funds for her businesses

loans.name: Jean Claude

texts.en:
Jean Claude is 24 years old, married with one child, three years old.  Jean Claude is commonly known in the business of selling clothes and he has been in this business for about 5 years.  He keeps his business open from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Jean Claude needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Jean Claude will purchase different styles of clothes.  With these different styles of clothes for sale, Jean Claude will earn more profits and he really hopes that the profits he earns will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business till he becomes a wholesaler supplying the retailers of his business area.

loans.use: different styles of clothes for sale

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
Cecile D. J. is a single woman who lives in Sitio Quiao, Brgy. Alijis, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a business venture: a general store.

Cecile joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Cecile has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,500, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 24,000 which she intends to use to buy additional items for the general store. She wants to use the extra profit to continue to save for the future. Cecile D. J. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. (Dungganon is a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable.) Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Meland

texts.fr:
Meland B. N. est un jeune homme de 26ans, célibataire sans enfant qui s’est lancé en 2004 dans le commerce  des pains pour palier au chômage après son cursus universitaire.

Il est dans la vente  des pains et friandises au coin de sa ruelle ou il a des bénéfice journaliers de 12000f et ses ventes sont considérables .
Avec cet argent il va acheter : 5cartons des  biscuits variés, 5 lots de sachets de chips,10 sachets des différents types de bonbons, 5paquets de  jus en carton , 2cartons de fromage en quartiers, 1paquets de sucreries,beurres,margarines, pates alimentaires.
Sa stratégie est de vendre à un prix  hors concurrence et  épargne petit à petit pour atteindre son objectif, devenir grossiste en commerce général.

Il va un jour fonder une famille et va se battre à réunir toutes les conditions nécessaires pour une vie meilleure.
Il est aussi encourager par son entourage qui veut qu'il soit un homme d'affaire connu
texts.en:
Meland B. N. is a 26-year old young man, single and without children. He began selling bread to cope with unemployment after he completed university.

He sells bread and treats on the side of his street, where he makes a daily profit of 12,000 francs, and sells a good amount of his products. With his loan he will buy: 5 cartons bags of chips, 10 bags of candy, butter, margarine, and pasta. His strategy for growing his business is to sell his products at low prices and save little by litte in order to one day become a wholeseller of general products.

He wants one day to begin a family and will fight to gather all the resources he needs to live a better life. He is also encouraged by his friends, who want him to become a well-known businessman.

loans.use: Achat des cartons de fromage, beurre ,margarine, pates alimentaires, sucreries

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion S. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Malinong, Brgy. Miranda, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a passenger transport business. Her husband, Jose S., who is 50 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living. He also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children who are 17 to 28 years old.

Consolacion joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Consolacion has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 14,000 which she intends to use to buy a tricycle so that she can continue to save for future home repairs and business expansion.

Consolacion S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. (Dungganon is a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable.) Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Maintenance of her motorcycle business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chicorral Group

texts.es: Doña Dorca es soltera, cursó el sexto grado de primaria, ella se dedica al comercio (compra y venta de ropa típica) tales como cortes: sarapados, altacedas, sedalinas, jaspes y entre otros, tiene 10 años ya con este negocio. Contando con entusiasmo y la ayuda de algunas vecinas organizan un grupo, para poder solicitar un préstamo. El Grupo solidario se  denomina Chicorral,  el nombré indica la ubicación de cada una de ellas. El grupo cuenta con seis integrantes mujeres, quienes se dedican a diversas actividades entre ellos podemos mencionar, la crianza de animales,  y venta de Cobijas, y ropa para niños.  El préstamo lo utilizarán para compra de mercadería  y así incrementar el volumen de ventas, con lo esperan tener mejores ganacias y mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Doña Dorca is single, finished sixth grade in primary school and dedicates herself to the commercial purchase and sale of typical clothing with complex silk embroidery and dyed threads and has had this business for ten years. With enthusiasm and the help of some neighbors they've organized a group in order to request a loan. The group is called Chicorral, the name indicates where the women are from. The group includes six integral women who dedicate themselves to diverse activities including the raising of animals, the sale of blankets, and the sale of clothing for children. They will use the loan to purchase merchandise and thereby increase the volume of sales with which they hope to have greater earnings and improve their condition of living.

Translated from Spanish by Tess Siemer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Osmar Silvino

texts.es:
El señor Osmar  tiene 30 años de edad, es soltero, vive con sus padres,  donde tiene instalado un  taller  mecánico de automóviles  desde hace  más de 5 años. 
 El taller pertenecía al padre pero actualmente Osmar esta a cargo, cuenta con todas las herramientas necesarias para poder realizar con eficiencia su trabajo. 
Solicita el préstamo a Fundación Paraguaya para la  compra de una nueva compresora  para así cumplir puntualmente a su clientela.
texts.en:
Mr. Osmar is 30, single, and he lives with his parents. More than 5 years ago an automobile repair shop was set up there. It belongs to his father but Osmar is currently in charge. The shop is equipped with all the necessary tools so that the work can be done efficiently. He is requesting a loan from Fundación Paraguaya to buy a new compressor so that the the work can be completed on time for the customers.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a compressor

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adrienne

texts.fr:
Femme de 48ans, célibataire et mère de 2 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 23ans et 18ans .Elle a commencée en 1978  à vendre  les patates douces grillées devant la parcelle de ses parents avec 2500f de fond.
Avec la réalité du pays, elle s’est lancé dans le commerce des habits en 2002 et ouvre une boutique avec étalage  à la devanture.
Par jour elle a des recettes de 7500f minimun et 20000f maximum, ses bénéfices sont considérables, ce prêt va lui permettre d’acheter dans les magasins de la place des  lots de  tee-shirts, des pantalons jeans pour enfants, 5 douzaines des  chemises mixtes, 3 douzaines  des robes pour fillettes, 3 douzaines de culottes pour petits garçons,10 d’ensembles sous vetements  pour dames.
Elle à pour vision de  faire plus de bénéfices et commencer dans la vente en gros,  elle est seule à subvenir aux  besoins des ses filles, car elle les soutien dans leurs études.
texts.en:
This 48-year old woman is single and the mother of two children, 23 and 18 years old. She got her start in business back in 1978, selling baked yams in front of her parents’ land plot, with a starting capital of 2500 francs. With the changing economic reality in the country, in 2002, she started selling clothing and opened a store with a stall in front. Her daily sales volume ranges between 7,500 and 20,000 West African francs. This is a considerable income. Her loan will allow her to purchase from local stores a supply of T-shirts, children’s jeans, five dozens of various types of shirts, three dozens of girls’ dresses, three dozens of pants for young boys, 10 sets of women’s lingerie. Her vision is to increase her revenues and to start selling wholesale. She alone provides for her daughters and supports their studies.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing T-shirts,pants, and shirts for children, as well as underwear

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en: Geraldine P. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Ampalaya, Brgy. Gun-ob, Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu City. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and pig fattening. Her husband Angelo P., who is 25 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living. They have a 5-year-old child. Geraldine joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Geraldine has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 14,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 25,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000, which she intends to use for the expansion of her pig-fattening business and to purchase a second-hand motorcycle so that she can continue to save up for the future, improve their house and expand their business. Geraldine P. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Expansion of her pig-fattening business and the purchase of a second-hand motorcycle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Esperance

texts.fr:
Célibataire de 46ans, mère de 2enfants dont l’âge varie entre 21ans et 10ans, avec son niveau d’étude secondaire, elle a une passion pour la coiffure et elle décide un jour, encouragée par ses copines qu’elle aimait faire les tresses, elle  ouvre un salon en pleine air dans la cour de la parcelle familiale en 2007 avec 3000f comme fond de démarrage.
Depuis 2009, elle gère un salon de coiffure  avec vente des produits  cométiques et capillaires.
Les tresses et les coiffures journalières lui rapportent 7000f et 15000f selon les jours (weekend, fêtes …). 
Avec le prêt,  elle va acheter 5 bidons de5 litres de shampooing,  bidons de 5litres de démêlants, 2gros pots de défrisants, 1gros pots de gèle coiffant, 5paquets de pinces, 5paquets de filets, 1 lots des peignes tiges, 20 paquets des différents mèches.
Elle voudra ouvrir un salon plus moderne ou elle veut utilisée les filles mères et faire plus de bénéfices afin de soutenir ses filles à faire des grandes études.
Sa famille  la soutien et l’encourage à aller de l’avant.
texts.en:
This entrepreneur is a single woman, 46 years old, with two children (21 and 10 years old). She has finished secondary studies. She has a passion for the hairdressing trade. One day in 2007, encouraged by her friends whose hair she enjoyed braiding, she opened her salon under the open sky, in the courtyard of her family residence, with 3000 as a starting capital. Since 2009, she has been managing a hairdresser salon and selling beauty and hair care products. Braiding and hair styling brings her an income between 7,000 and 15,000 per day (depending on whether it’s the weekend, holiday etc). With this loan, she is going to purchase five 5-liter cans of shampoo, as well as some 5-liter cans of hair straightener , two big jars of anti-frizz hair treatment, one big jar of hair gel, five packs of hair pins, one lot of combs, 20 packs of various hair extensions. She would like to open a more up-to-date salon where she would employ young single mothers and be able to achieve a higher revenue in order to provide for higher-level studies of her daughters. Her family supports her and encourages her to advance.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cans of hair straightener, shampoo; hair extensions, anti-frizz, hair gel, combs, hair pins etc.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en: Marites D. is a 41-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: selling used clothes and an at-home service for manicures and pedicures. She lives in Purok Kaimito, Brgy. Sangi, Toledo City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in selling used clothes and in her manicure and pedicure business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Marites is now borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Marites aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of stock to sell

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is 24 years old and he is married.  Innocent is a self-employed businessman selling a variety of cosmetic goods as his picture indicates.  He has been in this business for about 3 years and the hours of his business are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Innocent needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Innocent has a vision of wholesaling.  If he starts to wholesale goods to the retailers from his business area, he really hopes that his profits will increase which in turn will allow him to keep expanding his business for a better financial stability in the future.

loans.use: a variety of cosmetic goods for sale

loans.name: Eben Ezer Group

texts.es: Doña Olimpia  es divorciada, es una persona analfabeta, tiene 3 hijos los cuales dos  están casados y la otra  siguen a su cargo, ella se dedica a la crianza de animales domésticos  (Ganado Vacuno, Bovino, y pollos ponedoras), tambien a la Artesanía elaboración de Ponchos y blusas, tiene 10 años ya con este negocio. Contando con entusiasmo y la ayuda de algunas vecinas organizan un grupo, para poder solicitar un préstamo. El Grupo Solidario  se denomina Eben Ezer, El grupo cuenta con cinco  integrantes mujeres, quienes se dedican a diversas actividades entre ellos podemos mencionar, la crianza de animales, y crianza de animales domesticas,   El préstamo lo utilizarán para compra de materia prima y así incrementar el volumen de ventas, y generar mejores ganancias en cada una de las actividades que realizan.
texts.en:
Doña Olimpia is divorced and she is illiterate. She has 3 children, two are married and she is still responsible for a daughter. For a living she breeds domestic animals (cattle, sheep, and egg-laying chickens) and she also makes crafts such as ponchos and blouses. She has done this for 10 years. With her enthusiasm and the support from some neighbors, they have organized a group in order to request a loan. The solidary group is named Eben Ezer. The group has five female partners who carry out different activities such as breeding livestock as well as domestic animals. The loan will be spent on buying raw material and thus increase sales and generate higher profits for each of them.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital

loans.name: Francoise

texts.fr:
N. Françoise  est une femme de 49 ans, née à Gasabo, province de la Ville de Kigali capital du Rwanda. Elle est mariée elle a quatre enfants le moins âgée a  12 ans, le plus âgée a 20 ans, tous vont a l’école. Françoise et  sa famille habite à Kinyinya- Gasabo- Kigali, son niveau d’éducation est secondaire dans l’option de Biochimie. Elle est salariée dans une Eglise de PENTECOTE(ADEPR), Paroisse de Gasave ou elle est évangéliste de cette Eglise.
Le crédit contracté avec ACB est  le deuxième, le précédent lui a aidé d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et le présent prêt c’est pour réhabiliter  sa maison. Ses épargnes lui permettent  de payer le loyer ou elle habitait avec sa famille jusqu'à avoir sa maison laquelle elle veut réhabiliter.
Dans l’avenir, elle compte solliciter un nouveau prêt pour le minerval de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Françoise N. is a 49-year-old woman born in Gasabo, a province of Kigali, capital of Rwanda. She is married and has four children whose ages range between 12 and 20 years old. All attend school. Françoise and her family live in Kinyinya (in Gasabo, Kigali). She pursued secondary level studies in biochemistry. She works at a Pentecostal Church (ADEPR), in the parish of Gasave, where she is an evangelist. This is her second loan with ACB. The first loan helped to improve her family’s living conditions, whereas this new loan will be used for home renovations. Her savings allow her to pay the rent where she lives with her family until they can move into their house, which she wants to repair. In the future, she intends to seek another loan for her children’s tuition.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cement, boards, grillwork and sand for home repairs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open a photo studio shop

loans.name: La Union Del Ave Fenix Group

texts.es:
La unión del Ave Fénix es un grupo conformado por trece mujeres trabajadoras que decidieron llamarse así por que están seguras que la unión hace la fuerza. Ellas radican en San Miguel Xico, Valle de Chalco Solidaridad, Estado de México. Los integrantes de este grupo son: Ma Gabriela Ramírez (Venta de Barbacoa), Fidelia C. (Venta por Catalogo), Angélica R. (Venta de Cerámica), Andrea Dávila (Venta de Bisutería), Josefina E. (Venta de Antojitos), Esperanza Valentín (Venta de Productos Nutricionales), Carmen Martínez (Taller de Costura), Marisol García (Venta de Joyería), Beatriz Hernández (Venta de Pollo), Graciela R. (Venta de Abarrotes), Ana Karen Dávalos (Bisutería), María Teresa C. (Taquería) y Epifanía O. (Tienda de Ropa). 

Marisol de 40 años de edad, tiene una hija que estudia la secundaria, Marisol enviudo hace diez años, desde entonces ha tenido que trabajar el doble para sustentar a su familia ya que también su madre depende de ella. Marisol se dedica a la venta de joyería desde hace doce años y ha seguido con esta actividad porque es muy comercial, todos los días después de terminar con sus labores del hogar sale a ofrecer su mercancía en diferentes lugares como casas, tiendas, ya que para ella el tiempo vale oro y no desaprovecha cualquier oportunidad que se le presenta. Marisol surte una vez por semana ya que así puede tener variedad de aretes, pulseras y cadenas y mantener a su clientela. Sus meses de mayor venta son los días festivos y el mes de diciembre y por su puesto la mayoría de clientela son mujeres. Los planes de Marisol es poner una tienda de regalos para tener un mayor ingreso para su familia y poder darles lo necesario. El crédito lo invirtió para surtir un poco más. 

Ellas se sienten muy contentas por el apoyo que les brinda Kiva a través de Fundación Realidad y así cumplir sus metas.
texts.en:
The "Unión de Ave Fénix" group is formed by thirteen hard-working ladies who decided on the name as union makes strength. They live in San Miguel Xico, Valle de Chalco Solidaridad, Estado de Mexico. The members of the group are: Ma. Gabriela Ramírez (barbecued meat sale), Fidelia C. (sale from catalog), Angélica R. (ceramics sale), Andrea Dávila (costume jewellery sale), Josefina E. (Mexican snacks sale), Esperanza Valentín (nutrition products sale), Carmen Martínez (dressmaking), Marisol García (jewellery sale), Beatriz Hernández (chicken sale), Graciela R. (groceries), Ana Karen Dávalos (custome jewellery), María Teresa C. (tacos), and Epifanía Olmeda (Clothing store).

Marisol is 40 years old, she has a daughter in middle school. Marisol became a widow ten years ago and since then she has worked double in order to maintain her family as her mother also depends on her. Marisol has sold jewellery for twelve years and is continuing with this activity as it is very profitable. Every day when she has finished her chores she goes out to offer her merchandise at different places such as homes and stores. As time is worth gold to her she takes advantage of every opportunity given to her. Marisol stocks up once a week in order to have a variety of earrings, bracelets, and chains to keep her customers satisfied. She sells the most on holidays and during the month of December and obviously most of her customers are ladies. Marisol plans to set up a gift shop to obtain more profit for her family and be able to meet their needs. The loan will be spent on stocking up.

They are very pleased with the support offered by Kiva through Fundación Realidad that enables them to reach their goals.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw material for Mexican snacks, catalogs, bracelets,chains and rings.

location.town: Valle De Chalco Solidaridad  Estado De Mexico

loans.name: Outh

texts.fr:
Jeune homme de 22ans, célibataire sans enfants qui après ses études de menuiserie  en 2001 s’est lancé dans la fabrication et garnissage des fauteuils.

Il fabrique aussi des chaises, des poufs que les femmes utilisent  pour cuisiner, les tablettes et les genres de petites caisses en contre-plaqué que les commerçants utilisent comme coffre-fort pour garder les pièces d’argent.les ventes de ses différents articles lui rapportent 25000f à 75000f par semaine.

L’actuel prêt va lui permettre d’acheter : 10mètre de tissus pour les fauteuils, 3feuilles de contre-plaqués, 3 bastingues du bois blanc, 2bastingues du bois rouge, 10kilogrammes des pointes, 2 pots de colles, 1 pots de vernis et  la mousse (éponge).

Il a pour objectif d’ouvrir un grand atelier de menuiserie ou il va réinsérer  les enfants de la rue et soutenir sa petite sœur à apprendre la coupe et couture.
Il est soutenu par les frères de son entourage qui sont aussi ses encadreurs.
texts.en:
This is a 22-year-old young man who is unmarried and without any children. After studying furniture-making in 2001, he got started in making and stuffing armchairs. He also makes chairs, shelving, and a kind of small plywood cases that merchants use as strong-boxes for keeping their coins. Selling these different items brings in 25,000 to 75,000 francs a week for him. The current loan will enable him to buy: 10 meters of cloth for the armchairs, 3 sheets of plywood, 3 rails of white wood, 2 rails of red wood, 10 kg of nails, 2 containers of glue, 1 container of shellac, and some foam. His goal is to open a large furniture workshop, where he is going to re-integrate street children into society and to support his younger sister in learning dressmaking. He is supported by brothers around him who are also his frame makers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying boards, plywood, rails, nails, varnish, glue

loans.name: Fabrice

texts.fr:
Homme de 32ans célibataire et père d’un enfant âgée de 4ans. Ayant un niveau universitaire et n’ayant pu décrocher du travail, et ayant 3 personnes en charge, il se lança dans le commerce de vente de tissus en 2003 avec un capital de  200000frs. Sa recette journalière est de 15000 à 40000 frs.

 Avec  ce prêt elle compte acheter des différentes qualités de tissus de cérémonie, de soie, de super 100 et d’autres tissus de première marque dont la demande est forte

Comme son étalage est dans l’un des plus grand marche de Brazzaville, il use de beaucoup de stratégies pour épargner, attirer sa clientèle, et présenter les meilleurs prix a ses potentiels clients et ceux en dépit de la hausse des marchandise sur le marché.

A l'avenir il aimera être l’un des plus grands commerçant du marché et pourquoi pas de la ville, il veut aussi que sa famille prospère.
Dans son quartier il est le papa de tous les enfants car il est comique.
texts.en:
This single 32 year old man is the father of a 4 year old child. Having a university degree but unable to get a job, and with 3 people in his care, he started a business selling fabrics in 2003 with a starting capital of 200,000 frs. His daily receipts are between 15,000 and 40,000 frs. With this loan, he expects to buy different qualities of ceremonial, silk, super 100, and other high-quality fabrics, for which demand is high. As his window display is in one of the biggest markets in Brazzaville, he uses many strategies to attract and keep his clientèle and to offer the best price to potential clients, despite a rise in prices of merchandise on the market. In the future, he would like to be one of the most successful shopkeepers in the market, or perhaps even the city. He also wants his family to prosper. In his neighborhood, he is the papa of all the children because he is so funny.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ceremonial, silk and super 100 fabrics

loans.name: San Antonio Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “San Antonio” actualmente se encuentra en el XI ciclo y está conformado por personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Las reuniones D. banco comunal son cada treinta días en la oficina central de la Institución de Micro finanzas Arariwa que está ubicado en el distrito de Wanchaq provincia D. Cusco. La mayoría de los socios se dedican al comercio. 

William nació  en la ciudad de Cusco y tiene 35 años, Actualmente, William vive en la misma ciudad donde nació junto con su esposa sus tres hijos. Antes, William se dedicaba como supervisor de la Distribuidora “CAPELO” por los años 1996 hasta 2003 pero el negocio cambio de dueño y le despidieron. 

Decidido a empezar una nueva vida en el año 2004, William utilizo sus ahorros para abrir una pequeña ferretería, donde vende clavos, pinturas y muchas cosas más. Le pueden encontrar en su tienda los 7 días de la semana, desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche. 

Con su próximo préstamo, William que espera recibir S/. 1000 nuevos soles. Por el momento, su tienda esta modestamente equipado con las necesidades básicas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero D. préstamo para comprar accesorios para los baños, accesorios para luz eléctrica, accesorios para el agua y accesorios de desague. El anhelo D. socio es comprarse una casa y un local propio para la su ferretería. 

William es fundador D. banco comunal y la escogieron como el secretario porque es una persona puntual y responsable. Ya son varias veces que está en el cargo y le va muy bien gracias al carisma y buena voluntad que tiene.
texts.en:
The “San Antonio” communal bank is currently in its 11th loan cycle. It is made up of hard-working and enterprising people who are always seeking opportunities to get ahead, and to provide a better future for their children through their daily efforts. The communal bank's meetings take place every thirty days in the central office of the Arariwa Microfinance Institution, which is located in the Wanchaq district of Cusco province. Most of the members are involved in commerce. William was born in the city of Cusco and is 35 years old. Currently, William lives in the same city where he was born, together with his wife and his three children. Earlier, William worked as a supervisor for the “CAPELO” distributing company, from 1996 to 2003, but the business changed owners and William was laid off. Determined to start a new life in 2004, William used his savings to open a small hardware store, where he sells nails, paint and many other items. He can be found in his store 7 days a week, from 8 in the morning until 8 at night. For his next loan, William hopes to receive 1000 Peruvian new soles. For the moment, his store is modestly equipped with the basic necessities. He would like to use the funds from the loan to buy bathroom accessories, electric lighting accessories, and plumbing and drain supplies. William's desire for the future is to buy a house and a building of his own for his hardware store. William is a founding member of the communal bank, and he was chosen as secretary because he is a punctual and responsible person. He has served in this position several times, and it has gone very well for him, thanks to his charisma and good will.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bathroom, electric lighting, plumbing and drain supplies and accessories

loans.name: Brigitte  Angela

texts.fr:
femme de 45  ans celibataire et mère de 2 enfants dont l'âge varie de 12ans à 18ans tous scolarisés.après avoir perçu sa première bourse scolaire à l'université elle se lanca dans la  vente des boîtes de peintures et de sanitaires  au marché en 1990. 
En 1995 avec ses benefices elle ouvre une quincaillerie avec un capital de 500000frs.
avec ce prêt elle aimerait renforcer son activité en achetant carreaux, ampoules de tous genre, pinceaux,des robinets, prises et contacts pour l'electricite et autres materiaux  de construction.
Malgré la hausse des prix sur le marché elle à pour strategie d'épargner toutes les semaine, d'améliorer son étallage et de vendre a des  prix hors concurrence afin de mieux garder sa clientèlle. 
elle aimerait que son activité prospère de jour au jour ainsi que construire une maison pour ses enfants afin d'améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et instruire ses enfants, les encoureger et les aider dans leur scolarité.
Dans son quartier elle est encouragee car elle se bat à nourrir sa famille.
texts.en:
This 45 year old single woman is the mother of 2 children, aged between 12 and 18 years old, and both in school. After having using her first school loan to go to university, she started in the sale of cans of paints and toilets at the market in 1990. In 1995, with her profits, she opened a hardware store with a starting capital of 500,000 frs. With this loan, she would like to strengthen her business by buying tiles, light bulbs of all varieties, paintbrushes, sinks, electrical plugs and outlets and other construction materials. Despite a rise in market prices, she tries to save money every week, to improve her window dressing and to sell at prices below the competitive price in order to better maintain her clientèle. She would like her business to prosper from day to day, as well as build a house for her children in order to improve her family's living conditions and instruct, encourage and help her children get educated. In her neighborhood, she is encouraged because she must work hard to feed her family.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of paint, brushes, pikes, tiles, saws, lightbulbs, electrical plugs and outlets

loans.name: Zussette

texts.en:
Zussette G. is from the village of Salay Angadanan, Isabela. She is 30 years old and single. To make a living, Zussette runs a general store selling both food and daily-use products. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns 3000 Php monthly.

In 2008, Zussette joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI which was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. She is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Zussette from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Silvio

texts.es:
Silvio es  de la ciudad de Pilar, tiene 30 años y  está cursando el 4° año de la carrera de Ciencias Jurídicas en la Universidad Nacional de Pilar (UNP) en la ciudad de Pilar. El es el 2º hijo de 3 en la familia. Su madre es comerciante junto con su padre en la zona de Cerrito distante a 75 km de la ciudad de Pilar.

Silvio se encuentra trabajando en el Poder Judicial desde hace mas de 5 años, actualmente se desempeña como Ujier y a través de este trabajo que realiza le toca movilizarse por toda la zona del Departamento de Ñeembucú. Gracias a este trabajo el mismo se puede mantener y estudiar a la vez, está en los últimos años de la carrera que tiene muchos deseos de concluir. La finalidad de el mismo es el de poder contar el día de mañana de un excelente ingreso como para poder ayudar al progreso de su familia ya que son gentes de una zona muy humilde comento Silvio.

Actualmente es soltero y vive solo, pero piensa en el día de mañana poder contar con su familia propia y poder brindarle todas las comodidades.

El solicita el préstamo para el pago de la mensualidad de su facultad y también para la compra de libros que está necesitando para estudiar.
texts.en:
Silvio is from the city of Pilar. He is 30 years old and is in his 4th year of a degree in Judicial Science at the National University of Pilar (UNP). He is the second of three sons in his family. Silvio's mother and father have a business, in the Cerrito area, 75km from Pilar. Silvio has been working in the Justice Service for over 5 years. At the moment he works as a court usher, and through his work he travels throughout Ñeembucú Department. Thanks to his job, he is able to continue studying. Silvio is in the last years of his degree and very much wants to complete it. He says that completing it will mean he can count on an excellent salary and be able to help his family, who are from a very humble area. He is single and lives alone, but hopes that in future he will have a family of his own and be able to offer them everything they could want. He is seeking the loan to pay his monthly University tuition and also to buy books that he needs for his studies.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: University fees and books

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.fr:
femme de 43ans célibatiare et mère de 2 enfants dont l'âge varie entre 17ans et 2ans.après ses études secondaires,et n'ayant plus de soutien financier elle alla aider sa maman vendeuse de la layette au marche en 1995 et elle y prit goût , des que l'occasion se presenta et trouva un peu d'argent ,elle se lanca  aussi dans le commerce de layette en 2000 avec un capital de 10000frs.

avec ce prêt elle veut renforcer son activité en achetant les douzaine de couches,  lots de tricots, biberons, brassières, couverture,tetine, draps, poudre et d'autres produits de premiere necessité. 
Elle a une vente journaliere de 20.000 a 35000frs , ses clientes sont les femmes enceintes qui frequentent le marche
malgré les difficulté de rupture de stock des marchandises auprès de ses fournisseurs, sa strategie est d'avoir plusieurs variétés de marchandises,faire un bon acceuil, avoir un bon étallage afin de mieux satisfaire aux besoins de ses clients.
elle aimerait avoir une boutique dans le futur et etre grossiste ,aussi effectuer des voyages pour acheter de la marchandise, améliorer les conditions de scolarité de ses enfants.
dans son quartier on dit qu'elle est calme et polie
texts.en:
This 43 year old single woman is the mother of 2 children, between the ages of 2 and 27. After high school, without financial support, she began to help her mother to sell baby clothes at the market in 1995, and got a taste for it. Since then, her chance presented itself when she found some money, and she too began a business selling baby clothes in 2000 with a starting capital of 10,000 frs. With this loan, she wants to strengthen her business by buying dozens of bedtime clothes, knitted goods, bibs, baby's tops, covers, pacifiers, bed linens, powder and other necessaries. She has a daily receipt of between 20,000 and 35,000 frs. Her clients are pregnant women who frequent the market, despite difficulties arising from a break-down in the supply of merchandise from her providers. Her strategy is to have a large variety of merchandise, to create a good reception area, to have a good window display in order to better satisfy the needs of her clientèle. She would like to have a boutique in the future and to be a wholesaler, as well as to make journeys to buy merchandise and to improve her children's schooling conditions. In her neighborhood, she is said to be calm and polite.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy knit goods, baby tops, covers and bibs

loans.name: Mwero

texts.en: Mwero is a married woman with two children in school. Her  husband is a teacher and he contributes to his family's basic needs. Mwero has run her  business selling khangas (traditional African dress) door to door to her friends and neighbors for the last three years. With Kshs.40,000 she wants to purchase a bundle of khangas to increase her stock. Mwero faces a major challenge in high transportation costs and theft. Her major goal is to expand her business to earn more profit and improve her living standard. She lives in a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is electricity.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of khangas (traditional African dress).

loans.name: Unity Group

texts.en: R. S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Unity. R. is 40 years old and married with nine children who range from 6 months to 19 years old. He was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to lack of support. For 5 years, he has sold coconuts in West Point Market, down-town Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 4,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 24,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more coconuts. He describes himself as an earnest and hard-working man whose dream is to expand his business and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more coconuts.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena B. is from the village of Calamagui 1st. She is 55 years old and married with five adult children. To make a living, Magdalena owns a general store selling a variety of products. Magdalena has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Magdalena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Magdalena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Las Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
Esta unidad de desarrollo (UD) se llama “LAS TRABAJADORAS” porque el grupo se considera un grupo de persona trabajadoras y por eso se les ocurrió ese nombre. Las UDES son grupos de más de 10 personas que tiene una cuenta de banco y tienen que reunir semanalmente o quincenalmente para realizar sus pagos. Tiene un representante y un comité que lo gobierna. Este grupo está ubicado en la comunidad de Valle Verde en el estado de Michoacán. El grupo está conformado por 14 integrantes. 

La representante del grupo se llama Lidia. Doña Lidia tiene 41 años de edad, estudio hasta sexto de primaria, comenta que sus papas ya no la dejaron estudiar porque decían que era una pérdida de tiempo y dinero por que las mujeres nada mas servían para estar en la casa, por eso ella ya no siguió con sus estudios. Doña Lidia vive en unión libre con el señor Marco desde hace 12 años, don Marco Antonio se dedica hacer fletes y es jornalero, ellos procrearon a 3 hijos de nombres Rubí de 11 años de edad, que estudia la primaria, luego le sigue Joshua quien tiene 6 años y estudia el jardín de niños y Cielo que tiene 3 años. Doña Lidia pidió su préstamo para su negocio que es un molino de masa, ella tiene con su negocio hace aproximadamente 8 años ella empezó con ese tipo de negocio por que ya había trabajado en un molino y como cerca de su casa no había molinos decidió invertir en uno. Su préstamo lo va a invertir en compra de leña, maíz, cal, para el nixtamal y después molerlo y vender la masa. Uno de sus sueños es poder hacer a lado del local del molino una tienda de abarrotes y remodelar los locales ponerles las cortinas, aplanar las bardas  y pintarlos, ella espera que muy pronto pueda realizar sus metas. 

Dulce Lluvia, es parte de este grupo “Las Trabajadoras”, tiene 21 años, está estudiando el primer año de preparatoria, comenta que dejo de estudiar 7 años porque se fue Estados Unidos buscando el sueño americano como ella lo define, se tuvo que regresar a México porque se puso muy difícil la situación. Dulce tiene una niña de once meses es madre soltera y ayuda a sus padres con los gastos de su casa. Ella se dedica a la elaboración de pan de rancho, comenta que su mama ya tenía el negocio del pan y fue ella que le enseño a elaborar el pan, desde hace 10 años, Dulce está muy contenta porque le dieron su préstamo y con el va a invertir en leña, azúcar, harina, levadura, manteca etc. Ella vende su pan de casa en casa en diferentes localidades como son El Rincón, Granjeno, Zitacuaro y otras más. Dice que uno de sus sueños y metas en la vida es tener una panadería estable quiere rentar un local y poner su negocio para también estar más al pendiente de su hija.
Los otros 12 integrantes se llaman María Guadalupe, Elizabeth E. Sánchez, Librada, Mariana, María Esther, Daniel García, María Sara, Marco Antonio, Mireya, Reina, Jazmín Hernández  y Bertha. ellos quieren préstamos para venta de ropa, Tortillas a mano, guaracheria, venta de frutas, venta de dulces, etc.
texts.en:
This village bank is called "Las Trabajadoras" - "the working women" - because the members of the group consider themselves a hard-working group of women. The village banks are groups of 10 or more people who, together, hold a bank account and have to meet weekly or fortnightly to make their repayments. They have an elected representative and a committee which oversees the group. This group is based in the commun ity of Valle Verde, in the state of Michoacán. The group is made up of 14 members. The group's representative is Lidia. Lidia is 41 years old. She went to school until 6th grade: her parents, she says, would not let her continue. They thought it a waste of time and money, as women were only good for being housewives - this is the reason she could not continue her studies. Lidia lives with her partner, Marco, whom she has been with for 12 years. Marco works as a delivery driver and a labourer. They have three children: 11 year old Rubí, who is at primary school, 6 year old Joshua, who is at kindergarten, and Cielo, who is 3. Lidia is seeking her loan for her business, which is grinding corn. She has had the business for 8 years. She started it because she already had experience of working in a mill, and since there were no mills near her home, she decided to invest in one. Her loan will be used to buy firewood, maize and lime for the tortilla dough. She will grind the corn and sell the dough. One of her dreams is to set up a grocery store next to the mill, and to remodel the premises, put up curtains, sand the fences and paint them. She hopes that soon she will be able to realize these goals. Dulce Lluvia, also a member of the group, is 21 years old and studying in her first year of college. She says she left studying for 7 years, because she went to the United States - seeking the "American Dream" as she saw it. She had to return to Mexico, however, because the situation there was very difficult for immigrants. Dulce has a little girl, 11 months old. She is a single mother, and she helps her parents with the household expenses. She works baking bread: it was her mother who started the business and who, over 10 years ago, taught Dulce how to bake bread. Dulce is very happy at being granted this loan, which she will invest in firewood, sugar, flour, butter, etc. She sells her bread from door to door in different neighbourhoods, such as El Rincón, Granjeno and Zitacuaro. She says that one of her dreams is to have a proper bakery. She would like to rent premises and set up her business so she can provide better for her daughter. The other 12 members of the group are: María Guadalupe, Elizabeth, Librada, Mariana S. M., María Esther S. M., Daniel García C., María Sara, Marco Antonio, Mireya C., Reina M., Jazmín, and Bertha. They want their loans for a variety of enterprises, including selling clothes, making tortillas, making sandals out of recycled tyres, selling fruit, selling sweets, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood, maize and lime for making tortilla dough

loans.name: Family Tree Group

texts.en: George K., with the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Family Tree. George is 31 years old, single, and has two children aged 12 and 15. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of support. For 5 years, he has operated a motorbike transportation business on Water Street, in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 14,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 63,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy spare parts and petroleum. He describes himself as an earnest man whose goal is to improve his business and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy spare parts and petroleum

loans.name: Valérie

texts.fr:
N. Valerie est une femme de 44 ans, née à Gasabo, province de la Ville de Kigali capital du Rwanda. Elle est mariée elle a quatre enfants le moins âgée a  10 ans, le plus âgée a 18 ans, tous vont a l’école. Valérie et  sa famille habite à Kinyinya- Gasabo- Kigali, son niveau d’éducation est  primaire. Elle est salariée dans une Eglise de PENTECOTE(ADEPR), Paroisse de Gasave ou elle est évangéliste de cette Eglise.
Le crédit contracté avec ACB est  le cinquième, le précédent lui a aidé d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et le présent prêt c’est pour réhabiliter  sa maison. Ses épargnes lui permettent  de payer le loyer ou elle habitait avec sa famille jusqu'à avoir sa maison laquelle elle veut réhabiliter ou faire le finissage.
Dans l’avenir, elle compte solliciter un nouveau prêt pour le minerval de ses enfants.
texts.en:
N. Valerie is a 44 year old woman, born in Gasabo, in the province of the city of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. She is married and has four children between the ages of 10 and 18 years old, all in school. Valerie and her family live in Kinyinya- Gasabo- Kigali. She has a primary school education. She is paid by the Pentecote (Adepr) Church, Parish of Gasave, where she is a church evangelist. The loan she got from ACB is her fifth. The previous one helped her to improve her family's living conditions and her present loan is to renovate her house. Her savings allows her to pay the rent for where she lives with her family until they have the house, which she wants to renovate or finish. In the future, she expects to seek a new loan for her children's school fees.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of doors, windows, sand and cement

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred is a married woman with four children who all attend school. She has opened a private school which she has been operating for the past ten years. Her major customers are parents and pupils. With the 40,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase school text books to guide children when learning.

Mildred faces the major challenge of seasonality especially during holidays when schools have closed. She hopes that in future she will be able to renovate her school and provide a good learning environment for the students. She decided to work with Yehu in order to get financial assistance to improve her school. She lives in a rental house with electricity but no piped water. Mildred cites food as her greatest monthly expense.

loans.use: To purchase text books

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy building materials such as zinc, nails, wheelbarrows, paint, etc. to sell

loans.name: God’S Grace Group

texts.en:
James D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God’s Grace. James is 25 years old, single and was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of support. 

For four years, he has been selling second-hand shoes on Water Street, in downtown Monrovia, Liberia.
 
He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bags of second-hand shoes.

He describes himself as a quiet man. His dream is to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of second-hand shoes

loans.name: Abra Kafui Mawusse

texts.fr: A. abra est une femme de 43 ans, elle a une personne en charge, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce des articles de mercerie. elle fait ce commerce depuis 2006 dans son propre atelier. ce commerce marche bien pour elle. elle a déjà obtenu deux crédits qu'elle a remboursé sans grandes difficultés, elle sollicite de WAGES un  troisième crédit pour gonfler son stock avec 20 unités de fils à coudre, 10 douzaines de popelines et 8 douzaines d'épingle.
texts.en:
A. Abra is a 43 year old woman, with one person in her care. She runs a dry-goods store. She has run this business since 2006 in her own workshop. Her business runs well for her. She has already obtained two loans that she paid back without any large problems, and she is asking WAGES for a third loan to replenish her stock with 20 units of sewing thread, 10 dozen poplins, and 8 dozen pins.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase dry goods

loans.name: Lopito

texts.en:
Lopito G. is from the village of Sto. Domingo, Alicia, Isabela. He is 55 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Lopito owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Lopito has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP monthly from this activity.

In 2010, Lopito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This will be the first loan which Lopito has taken out from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Thank God Group

texts.en:
Yarie S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Thank God. Yarie is 35 years old, married and has three children who are between two and nine years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of financial support. 

For three years, she has been selling cold water and charcoal on Peace Island outside Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bags of cold water and charcoal to sell. 

She describes herself as a determined woman. Her goal is to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cold water and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Carlos Cesar

texts.es: El Sr. C. S. Carlos Cesar tiene 43 años de edad. Vive con su esposa e hijo. Tiene casa propia, la cual se encuentra ubicada en el distrito de Santiago. Trabaja como obrero de campo y en algunas oportunidades como albañil. Su esposa es empleada del Hogar. El Sr. Carlos es una persona muy emprendedora que a logrado salir adelante construyendo parte de su vivienda. Requiere el crédito para poder terminar de construir su vivienda. Su sueño, según nos comenta es terminar de construir dicha vivienda, para poder darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida. El Sr. C. está muy agradecido por el apoyo que le podamos brindar a través de este financiamiento.
texts.en:
Señor C. S. Carlos Cesar is 43 years old and lives with his wife and son. He has his own house, which is located in the Santiago district. He works as a farm labourer, and when the opportunity arises, as a bricklayer. His wife looks after their home. Carlos is a very emterprising person and he has succeeded in building part of their home. He needs the loan to be able to finish the construction. His dream, he tells us, is to finish building said dwelling, to be able to give his family a better quality of life. He is very grateful for the support we can offer him through this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home improvements

loans.name: Justo Pastor

texts.es: Justo Pastor se ha caracterizado por ser un hombre responsable, que día a día se preocupa por mejorar su negocio. Su actividad económica es la venta de leña y madera, el tiene más de 18 años de trabajar con este negocio, que ha sido muy importante pues con esta actividad ha llevado el pan de cada día a familia, el tiene 3 hijos menores de edad a su cargo, por lo que siempre está buscando la forma de mejorar sus ingresos. Este financiamiento lo realiza para la compra de materia prima como leña y madera pues actualmente tiene muchos encargos. Siempre sueña con mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Justo Pastor describes himself as a responsible man, who strives to improve his business day by day. His work is the sale of timber and firewood, which he has been doing for over 18 years and which is very important to him, as it has put bread on his family's table ech day for that time. He has 3 school-age children in his care, and so he is always looking for opportunities to boost his income. With this loan he will buy raw materials like timber nad firewood because he has a lot of orders to fill at the moment. He dreams, always, of improving his home.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Biakou Essi

texts.fr: G. est une femme mariée et mère de 2 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d'adidogomé qui est un  quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé. elle a ouvert un salon de coiffure qu'elle a appelé "coiffure extra". elle y a associé plus tard le commerce de produits cosmétiques. sa clientèle ne cesse de grandir car elle accueille bien ses clients et leur offre des produits de qualité. elle souhaite faire croître le commerce de produits cosmétiques. elle sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour l'achat de 4 cartons de divers produits cosmétiques.
texts.en:
Mrs. G. is married and the mother of 2 children. She lives with her family in the Adidogomé neighborhood, on the outskirts of the city of Lomé. She opened a hair styling salon which she named "Coiffure Extra." Later, she began to sell cosmetic products as well. The number of customers is always growing, as she takes good care of them and sells quality products. Mrs. G. wants to increase her business in cosmetic products. She is asking WAGES for her first loan, in order to buy 4 boxes of assorted cosmetic products.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cosmetic products

loans.name: Marilu Flor

texts.es:
Marilu de 43 años, ella vende productos Omnilife (productos naturales) y vive en una zona periurbana de Guayaquil llamada “Fortín” y caracterizada por su pobreza y sus caminos de tierra. 

Antes de vender los productos Omnilife ella era enfermera en un policlínico pero como necesitaba pasa mas tiempo con sus hijos decidió retirarse y comenzar a vender productos para el bienestar de la salud de las personas. Ahora ella vende productos como Maynus bote, OML plus, teatino etc. Estos ayudan a las enfermedades que afectan al cuerpo. 

Para seguir con las ventas de los productos Omnilife quiere comprar con el préstamo Teatino, OML plus porque son los mas pedidos. En el futuro quiere seguir incrementando su negocio y que sus hijos se gradúen con éxito.
texts.en:
Marilu is 43 years old. She sells "Omnilife" natural products and lives in an area called "Fortin", on the outskirts of Guayaquil, which is characterised by its poverty and dirt roads. Before she started selling Omnilife products, Marilu was a nurse in a private hospital, but wanted more time with her children and decided to leave her job and start selling products that would improve people's health and wellbeing. Now she sells products like Maynus bote, OML plus, and teatino, which alleviate ailments that affect the body. To carry on selling Omnilife products, she wants to use this loan to buy Teatino and OML plus, as they get the most orders. As for the future, she wants to continue growing the business and hopes that her children grow up to be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy "Omnilife" branded natural prducts

loans.name: Ahmenou Group

texts.en:
Annie M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Ahmenou. She is 52 years old, married and has five children who range from 12 to 30 years old. 

She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. 

For two years, she has been operating a mini restaurant in Sinkor in Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more rice, oil, beans, meat, fish, onions, tomatoes, etc. She describes herself as a determined woman.

Her goals are to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more rice, oil, beans, meat, fish, onions, tomatoes, etc.

loans.name: God Give And Increase Group

texts.en:
Sabah J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Give And Increase. Sabah is 47 years old, married and has two children, who are 18 and 30 years old. 

She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of financial support. 

For three years, she has been manufacturing and selling a locally manufactured soap called "iron soap" in the Rally Town market in Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more red oil and caustic used in the production of the soap. She describes herself as a kind woman.

Her dream is to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more red oil and caustic used in the production of the soap

loans.name: Real Atahuallpa Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “Real Atahuallpa” actualmente se encuentra en el XII ciclo y está conformado por personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Las reuniones del banco comunal son cada treinta días en la oficina central de la Institución de Micro finanzas Arariwa que está ubicado en el distrito de Wanchaq provincia del Cusco. La mayoría de los socios se dedican al comercio.  

Mónica nació  en la ciudad de Cusco y tiene 33 años, Actualmente, Mónica vive en la misma ciudad donde nació junto con su esposo sus dos hijos. Antes, Mónica vendía ceviche de forma ambulatoria en la esquina de la calle Dolorospata del distrito de Santiago pero como hay mucha contaminación por la zona cerró el negocio.   

Decidido a empezar una nueva vida, Mónica utilizo sus ahorros para abrir una pequeña tienda de abarrotes, donde vende arroz, azúcar y muchas cosas más. Le pueden encontrar todos 7 días de la semana, desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche. 

Con su próximo préstamo, Mónica que espera recibir S/. 300 nuevos soles. Por el momento, su tienda esta modestamente equipado con las necesidades básicas. Le gustaría emplear el dinero del préstamo para comprar tarjetas de llamadas. El anhelo del socio es abrir una tienda más grande o tener una cebichería. Mónica es una de los socias fundadores del banco comunal y es una persona puntual y responsable.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Real Atahuallpa" is now in its 12th loan cycle. It is made up of hardworking and enterprising people who are always on the lookout for opportunities to get ahead, and who make a daily effort to provide a better future for their children. The group meets every 30 days in the central offices of the Institución de Micro finanzas Arariwa, which is located in the Wanchaq district of Cusco province. The majority of the members work in retail trade. Monica, 33, was born in the city of Cusco. She now lives in the city where she was born with her husband and their 2 children. Before, Monica used to work as a street vendor selling ceviche on the corner of Dolorospata street in the Santiago district, but as there is a lot of pollution in the area she closed that business. Determined to start a new life, Monica used her savings to open a small grocery store where she sells rice, sugar and many other items. There you can find her every day of the week, from 6 in the morning until 8 at night. With her next loan, Monica hopes to receive 300 Peruvian soles. Right now, her store is modestly supplied with the basic necessities. Monica would like to use the money from the loan to buy calling cards. She would like to open a store that is bigger, or have a seafood restaurant. Monica is one of the founding members of the communal bank, and she is a person who is responsible and punctual.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy calling cards

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.es:
Eulalia pertenece al Banco Comunal Obreras hace 10 años y lo que mas le agrada son las reuniones amenas con sus compañeras además que le enseñaron a ser puntual.
Eulalia es conviviente, tiene 7 hijos de los cuales 1 estudia, Eulalia tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes, verduras, actividad que realiza todos los días, además Eulalia vende relojes que reparte a amigos y familiares.
Eulalia solicita un crédito de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azucar, aceite.
Los sueños de Eulalia son comprar un carro para su distracción.
texts.en:
Eulalia has belonged to the communal bank "Obreras" for 10 years, and what she finds most enjoyable are the entertaining meetings with her fellow group members who, in addition, taught her to be punctual. Eulalia lives with a partner and has 7 children, 1 of whom is in school. Eulalia has a store in her house where she sells groceries and vegetables every day.
